questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 2 episodes of loss of consciousness over the past week. She recovered immediately and was not confused following the episodes. During the past 5 months, she has also had increased shortness of breath and palpitations. She has been unable to carry out her daily activities. She also reports some chest tightness that resolves with rest. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She immigrated with her family from India 10 years ago. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 115/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows accentuation and splitting of S2. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur in the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these findings?

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) is seen in left heart failure, but this patient demonstrates signs of mitral stenosis (MS). MS causes a decrease in LVEDP due to impaired ability to fill the left ventricle in diastole through the stenotic valve.

B) INCORRECT:

Left-to-right shunting may be present in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) or an atrial septal defect (ASD). However, this patient's cardiovascular examination is consistent with mitral stenosis (opening snap with low-pitched diastolic murmur at the apex). She does not have a murmur that suggests a VSD or ASD (holosystolic murmur).

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased left ventricular contractility may be due to ischemic or nonischemic cardiomyopathy. A decrease in contractility may lead to left heart failure, increased left heart pressures, and subsequent right heart failure. However, the patient shows signs of mitral stenosis (MS), left atrial dilatation, and right ventricular hypertrophy, suggesting that MS is the underlying mechanism and not left ventricular failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased systemic arterial resistance can be seen in patients with essential hypertension or secondary causes of hypertension. This may eventually lead to left ventricular hypertrophy which can evolve into diastolic dysfunction. As this patient shows right axis deviation on ECG, she is unlikely to have left ventricular hypertrophy. Additionally, the patient has normal blood pressure on examination, which suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Preload to the right ventricle is determined by central venous pressure and venous return to the heart and may be increased in states that expand blood volume (such as congestive heart failure). While this patient shows signs of right-sided heart failure, the presence of mitral stenosis with right axis deviation suggests a different underlying mechanism of the patient's disease.

F) CORRECT:

Mitral stenosis leads to increased left atrial pressure, causing both left atrial dilatation, which may result in atrial fibrillation, and an increase in pulmonary arterial pressure to overcome the increased left heart pressure (pulmonary hypertension). Over time, this will lead to pulmonary vascular remodeling, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, splitting of S2, and right ventricular hypertrophy (as indicated by the right axis deviation) to compensate. Right ventricular failure eventually manifests with characteristic features such as jugular venous distention and pitting edema.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: This patient has features of mitral stenosis (opening snap and diastolic murmur along with atrial fibrillation) that has progressed and caused further hemodynamic changes. Mitral stenosis commonly occurs as a late complication of rheumatic fever, which is more common in developing countries where patients may not have been adequately treated.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a 5-month history of progressive bilateral ankle swelling and shortness of breath on exertion. He can no longer walk up the stairs to his bedroom without taking a break. He also constantly feels tired during the day. His wife reports that he snores at night and that he sometimes chokes in his sleep. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He has a history of hypertension treated with enalapril. His pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. There is jugular venous distention. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The extremities are warm and well perfused. There is 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. ECG shows right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy can be caused by chronic hypertension and may result in left heart failure. Dysfunction of the left ventricle is a common cause of left heart failure, as it results in decreased cardiac output and backup of blood into the left ventricle. While left ventricular failure may lead to right ventricular dysfunction, signs of left ventricular dysfunction (e.g., orthopnea, pulmonary edema, cool extremities) are still expected. This patient, however, presents with signs of isolated right heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemic heart disease may manifest with dyspnea on exertion and fatigue, and it is common in patients with hypertension and a long history of smoking. However, other findings expected in ischemic heart disease, such as episodes of retrosternal chest pain or pressure (angina) or evidence of myocardial ischemia on ECG (e.g., ST-segment abnormalities, T-wave inversion), are not seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Snoring, restless sleep (occasionally choking during sleep), and chronic fatigue are suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), for which smoking is a risk factor. OSA causes hypoxia during apneic episodes, which leads to hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. Severe and long-standing OSA causes a constant increase in pulmonary pressure, which can result in right ventricular dysfunction. Impaired function of the right ventricle due to pulmonary hypertension resulting from a primary disorder of the respiratory or pulmonary artery system is referred to as cor pulmonale.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease can be caused by chronic hypertension (hypertensive nephropathy) and may manifest with fatigue, bilateral ankle edema due to protein loss, and dyspnea due to fluid overload, which can result in pulmonary edema. However, in pulmonary edema, crackles are typically heard on pulmonary examination. Furthermore, hypertensive nephropathy results in left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with lung cancer (i.e., pulmonary neoplasia) may also present with fatigue and shortness of breath. This patient's 25-year history of smoking puts him at risk of lung cancer. However, given the absence of cough, hemoptysis, or other constitutional or paraneoplastic symptoms, lung cancer is unlikely. Moreover, pulmonary neoplasia is unlikely to cause symptoms of right heart failure. This patient's history of snoring and nocturnal choking suggests another etiology of his right ventricular dysfunction.

F) INCORRECT:

Alveolar destruction is a finding in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), another common cause of pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale. COPD can manifest with dyspnea and pitting edema, and it is very likely to occur in patients with a long history of smoking. However, other findings typically expected in COPD, such as a chronic productive cough (lasting ≥ 3 months over 2 consecutive years) or signs of obstruction on lung auscultation (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds), are not seen here. Moreover, this patient's history of snoring and choking at night makes another cause of his symptoms more likely.
questions.hint: The physical examination findings (bilateral ankle swelling, exertional dyspnea, increased jugular venous pressure) and right axis deviation on ECG suggest right ventricular dysfunction.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Five years ago, she emigrated from Eastern Europe. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. She has a history of methamphetamine and cocaine use but quit 5 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jugular venous pulsations 9 cm above the sternal angle. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is a normal S1 and a loud, split S2. An impulse can be felt with the fingers left of the sternum. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. The fingertips are enlarged and the nails are curved. There is pitting edema around the ankles bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows pronounced central pulmonary arteries and a prominent right heart border. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: High-resolution CT scan of the lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polysomnography is the test of choice to diagnose obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which can cause group 3 pulmonary hypertension and subsequent right-sided heart failure (cor pulmonale). However, this patient lacks other typical features of OSA, such as restless sleep with excessive daytime sleepiness, snoring, apneic episodes, and impaired cognitive function. Furthermore, her presentation is consistent with an alternate subgroup of pulmonary hypertension and polysomnography will not confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) can be used to diagnose pulmonary embolism (PE). Chronic thromboembolic disease can cause group 4 pulmonary hypertension, and would fit with the duration of her symptoms, however V/Q scan is actually preferred as it is more sensitive for this diagnosis. Furthermore, her presentation is consistent with an alternate subgroup of pulmonary hypertension and CTA will not confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Doppler echocardiography is always part of the initial diagnostic investigation in patients with suspected pulmonary hypertension to estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PASP) as well as valvular and ventricular function. While transthoracic echocardiography is often sufficient to make a diagnosis and guide therapy, a different test is more likely to confirm this patient's diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT scan of the lung is used in the diagnosis of interstitial lung disease (ILD), which can cause group 3 pulmonary hypertension. ILD may cause fatigue, dyspnea, and clubbing of the nails. However, ILD typically also manifests with bibasilar, inspiratory crackles on auscultation, and reticular opacities on chest x-ray. This patient's presentation is more consistent with an alternate subgroup and CT will not confirm the diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Right-heart catheterization is the confirmatory test of choice for the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension as well as the specific subgroup, in this case pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Diagnosis is made when the mean pulmonary artery pressure is ≥ 20 mm Hg at rest and there is no evidence of underlying pulmonary and left heart conditions (e.g., valvular heart disease, systolic dysfunction, diastolic dysfunction). While PAH is often idiopathic, amphetamine and cocaine use have been associated with development of PAH. This patient has evidence of right-sided heart failure from her PAH, resulting in cor pulmonale. This indicates a worse prognosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing can be used to diagnose certain connective tissue diseases, such as scleroderma (SSc), which are associated with group 1 pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary arterial hypertension). This patient lacks other typical features of SSc, such as hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and dysphagia. Moreover, serologic testing would only confirm the presence of a connective tissue disorder, not confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

G) INCORRECT:

Spirometry is used to diagnose obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) and restrictive lung disease, which can cause group 3 pulmonary hypertension. While her smoking status and symptoms could be consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, her overall presentation is suggestive of an alternate subgroup of pulmonary hypertension and spirometry will not confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with dyspnea, evidence of right-sided heart failure (peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, split S2), and pronounced central pulmonary arteries, all of which are strongly suggestive of pulmonary hypertension, likely related to her history of drug use. Correct diagnosis is imperative, as treatment options vary between types of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath, abdominal discomfort, and swelling of his legs. He does not have fever, chills, or chest pain. He has had a cough and occasional episodes of dyspnea during the past 4 years but has not seen a physician in 15 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks three to four cans of beer daily. He appears fatigued. Pulse is 94/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 150/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Cardiac examination discloses distant heart sounds and a right parasternal heave. There is jugular venous distension. Auscultation of the lungs shows diffuse expiratory wheezes. The liver edge is palpated 3–4 cm below the right costal margin. An abdominal fluid wave is present. There is pitting edema below the knees. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for fluid retention in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although chronic constrictive pericarditis can manifest with progressive dyspnea and features of RHF, this patient has none of the characteristic features of constrictive pericarditis, such as Kussmaul sign, pulsus paradoxus, or pericardial knock on cardiac auscultation. This patient with a history of heavy smoking along with chronic cough and dyspnea has a different underlying cause for RHF.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's heavy alcohol use is a risk factor for chronic malnutrition, which can cause fluid retention as a result of hypoalbuminemia (in protein-energy malnutrition) and/or congestive cardiomyopathy (in thiamine and/or selenium deficiency). Hypoalbuminemia as a result of malnutrition does not explain this patient's RHF. Patients with congestive cardiomyopathy due to malnutrition typically present first with features of left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary rales) and later progress to RHF. This patient, however, presents with features of isolated RHF.

C) CORRECT:

Chronic pulmonary hypertension (PH) leading to cor pulmonale is the most likely cause of this patient's RHF. This patient with a history of heavy smoking presents with chronic cough and dyspnea, diffuse expiratory wheezes, and pulmonary hyperinflation (distant heart sounds), which indicates chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). COPD causes chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction which progresses to irreversible remodeling of the walls of the pulmonary arteries, resulting in group 3 PH. In a patient with COPD, a right ventricular strain pattern on ECG or worsening dyspnea or exercise intolerance with stable spirometry findings raise suspicion for PH. If PH is left untreated, the chronically elevated right ventricular afterload eventually causes reduced right-sided cardiac output (i.e., RHF). Reduced output of the right heart leads to elevated central venous pressure and systemic venous congestion, resulting in fluid accumulation in various tissues (e.g., liver, kidneys, peripheral tissue). Elevated central venous pressure also impairs lymphatic drainage, contributing to fluid retention.

If clinical suspicion is high for PH, perform transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) to noninvasively identify markers of elevated pulmonary artery pressure. Right heart catheterization is the confirmatory test for pulmonary hypertension. The causes of PH are classified into five groups: (1) idiopathic or hereditary, (2) left-sided heart disease, (3) chronic hypoxic lung disease, (4) chronic thromboembolism, and (5) unclear multifactorial mechanisms.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) can cause fluid retention and this elderly patient has not received care in the past 15 years for comorbidities such as hypertension, which is an important risk factor for the development and progression of CKD. Patients with CKD can develop worsening of preexisting heart failure (i.e., cardiorenal syndrome), but CKD alone does not explain the isolated RHF in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's heavy alcohol use is a risk factor for alcohol-associated liver disease, which can lead to cirrhosis and cause fluid retention in the form of ascites. Ascites is a late symptom of cirrhosis and indicates hepatic decompensation. This patient does not have other clinical features of cirrhosis, such as jaundice, pruritus, palmar erythema, spider angioma, caput medusae, or gynecomastia. Therefore, this patient's hepatomegaly and ascites are more likely a result of fluid retention due to RHF. Unlike cirrhosis, RHF usually causes hepatic venous congestion and ascites before it causes liver fibrosis.
questions.hint: The combination of jugular venous distention, right parasternal heave, hepatomegaly, ascites (positive abdominal fluid wave), and pedal edema without evidence of pulmonary edema (e.g., bibasilar crackles on chest auscultation) indicates that isolated right-sided heart failure (RHF) is the cause of fluid retention.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the emergency department because of leg swelling for 2 weeks. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, and pitting edema of both lower extremities. Cardiac examination shows a regular heart rate and normal heart sounds. Auscultation of the lungs shows scattered wheezing without crackles. Left ventricular ejection fraction is 60%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Left-sided heart failure with systolic dysfunction
Chronic occlusion of the pulmonary vessels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive collagen deposition in the pulmonary tissue and arteries is characteristic of connective tissue disorders such as systemic sclerosis. This process can cause inflammation, interstitial thickening, and vascular dysfunction, which can result in pulmonary arterial hypertension and subsequent right-sided heart failure. However, right heart failure secondary to connective tissue disorders is commonly a late complication that is preceded by a long history of systemic symptoms (skin manifestations, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility). Furthermore, this patient' s history of COPD makes a different cause much more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Left-sided heart failure (LHF) with systolic dysfunction (i.e., reduced left ventricular ejection fraction) can lead to pulmonary vascular congestion with increased pulmonary venous pressure and subsequent pulmonary hypertension. Over time, this can result in right ventricular strain, hypertrophy, and, ultimately, right-sided heart failure. Although LHF with systolic dysfunction is the most common cause of right-sided heart failure, it is unlikely to be the underlying cause of this patient's condition, since he has a normal ejection fraction (∼ 60%) and shows no signs of left-sided heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema with dyspnea, bilateral basilar rales).

C) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) arises from the incomplete closure of the ventricular septum during fetal development. Initially, VSDs cause a left to right shunt that increases blood flow through the pulmonary circulation. The resulting pulmonary hypertension can then, over time, cause right ventricular hypertrophy and subsequent right-sided heart failure. A VSD is unlikely in this patient given absence of a holosystolic murmur and his age.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic occlusion of the pulmonary vessels (e.g., chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension) is a form of pulmonary hypertension that can also lead to right-sided heart failure. However, this patient has no history of major risk factors (e.g., immobilization, hypercoagulability, malignancy) and a different etiology is much more likely given his underlying COPD.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's right-sided heart failure is most likely related to chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction due to his COPD (e.g., cor pulmonale). COPD is characterized by pulmonary inflammation resulting in fibrosis, airway obstruction, and capillary loss. Subsequent hypoxia and hypercapnia cause compensatory pulmonary vasoconstriction. The combination of hypoxic vasoconstriction and chronic inflammation triggers vascular remodeling, which, in turn, causes elevated pulmonary capillary pressure and pulmonary hypertension. Chronic, untreated pulmonary hypertension puts a strain on the right ventricle, causing concentric hypertrophy and progressive decline in right cardiac function, eventually leading to symptoms of decompensated right heart failure, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Hepatomegaly, bilateral pitting edema, and JVD are consistent with right-sided heart failure.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Constriction of the renal afferent arteriole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In cases of systemic hypoperfusion, reduced renal perfusion results in dilatation of the afferent arteriole via myogenic autoregulation and the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism, as well as constriction of the efferent arteriole via an increase in angiotensin II synthesis. Afferent arteriole dilation and efferent arteriole constriction then work in combination to maintain a constant GFR despite decreased cardiac output. Right heart failure is a condition that can cause systemic hypoperfusion. For this reason dilatation (not constriction) of the renal afferent arteriole would rather be expected in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension involves increased afterload of the right ventricle, resulting in reduced right ventricular output. Reduced right-sided cardiac output leads to venous congestion in the vessels that drain into the right heart, including the coronary sinus, which can become dilated as a result.
Image Description:

The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart. It lies in the left posterior atrioventricular groove and opens into the right atrium.

Main tributaries of the coronary sinus:
- Great cardiac vein: lies in the left anterior atrioventricular groove; receives the anterior interventricular vein that begins at the cardiac apex
- Small cardiac vein: lies in the right posterior atrioventricular groove; receives the right marginal vein and the anterior veins of the right ventricle
- Middle cardiac vein: lies in the posterior interventricular groove
- Posterior vein(s) of the left ventricle: lies to the left of the middle cardiac vein

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased left ventricular contractility is the hallmark of systolic left heart failure. Although left heart failure can lead to right heart failure, PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure (> 18 mm Hg). This patient's normal PCWP makes left heart failure unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve leaflet thickening can occur in mitral valve diseases such as mitral stenosis (e.g., due to rheumatic fever). Mitral valve disease usually results in increased left atrial pressure and therefore increased PCWP, whereas PCWP is normal in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (heart failure cells) are typically seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary congestion due to blood leakage into the alveolar spaces. Conditions that cause chronic pulmonary venous congestion include left heart failure and mitral stenosis. PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure and mitral stenosis, whereas it is normal in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Accumulations of hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as siderophages (examples indicated by blue overlay), are visible within alveoli. Additionally, alveoli filled with erythrocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen.

Siderophages in pulmonary alveoli (heart failure cells) suggest decompensated heart failure.
questions.hint: The presence of jugular venous distention suggests right heart failure, which can manifest with findings such as exertional shortness of breath and chest pain, as seen here. Antiphospholipid syndrome can cause pulmonary embolism, resulting in pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. A mean pulmonary artery pressure ≥ 25 mm Hg at rest confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, and a normal PCWP (4–12 mm Hg) excludes left heart failure as the cause.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. There is no family history of serious illness. She does not smoke. She takes diethylpropion to control her appetite and, as a result, has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during the past 5 months. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 115 kg (254 lb); BMI is 44 kg/m2. Her pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a loud pulmonary component of the S2. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's shortness of breath?

choices.text: Blockade of the right bundle branch

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophy of the interventricular septum is seen in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. While this condition can cause shortness of breath, it is characterized by an outflow obstruction in the left ventricle, not the right ventricle. Thus, an aortic systolic ejection murmur or paradoxical split S2 would be expected, not the loud pulmonary component of S2 seen in this patient. Furthermore, neither an S4 expected of a noncompliant hypertrophied ventricle nor a family history of sudden cardiac death in young relatives is present with this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Permanent enlargement of distal airspaces is seen in emphysema. While emphysema can cause shortness of breath and may cause pulmonary hypertension, this patient does not have any emphysema risk factors, such as extensive smoking history or signs of alpha 1 antitrypsin disease (e.g., hepatomegaly).

C) CORRECT:

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of pulmonary vascular walls is the underlying cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension, which can result from toxicity caused by sympathomimetic appetite suppressants and presents with dyspnea on exertion. This patient's heart sounds are typical of pulmonary hypertension, which initially presents with a prominent S2. Increased resistance of the pulmonary vasculature in pulmonary arterial hypertension limits right ventricular cardiac output; as it progresses, right ventricular failure can develop (e.g., cor pulmonale).

D) INCORRECT:

Right bundle branch block (RBBB) is a cardiac conduction deficit that can cause a widely split S2. Although RBBB can manifest with dyspnea due to underlying diseases, it is typically asymptomatic.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the pulmonary interstitium is seen in pulmonary fibrosis. While dyspnea and fatigue are typical of this disease, a persistent dry cough would also be expected. Furthermore, unlike bleomycin, methotrexate, and amiodarone, diethylpropion is not known to cause pulmonary fibrosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the pulmonary valve can cause pulmonary stenosis, resulting in fatigue, dyspnea, and splitting of S2. Calcification of the pulmonary valve is rare but can occur secondary to congenital heart disease, carcinoid heart disease, or age-related changes. This patient is not in a high-risk age group nor does she have any signs of congenital or carcinoid heart disease which would suggest calcification.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are likely due to a catastrophic adverse effect of diethylpropion, a sympathomimetic appetite suppressant. The accentuated pulmonary component of the second heart sound is the key to diagnosing this patient's condition.

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain during exercise for the last 6 months. She does not smoke. Her maternal uncle had similar symptoms. Cardiac examination shows wide splitting of S2. The second component of S2 is loud and best heard at the 2nd left intercostal space. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's cardiac findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although eventually possible, increased RV preload is not typically caused by pulmonary hypertension since diastolic filling occurs after pulmonary valve closure. Increases in RV preload can occur if pulmonary regurgitation secondary to pulmonary hypertension is present. Other common causes include a hypervolemic state, failing RV, or tricuspid regurgitation. Any of these conditions could explain this patient's exertional chest pain, fatigue, and breathlessness. However, additional signs of edema, elevated jugular venous pressure, and possibly gallops would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

There is minor, if any, right-to-left shunting in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Right-to-left shunting can occur intrapulmonary or extrapulmonary. Intrapulmonary right-to-left shunting occurs in patients with any cause of increased physiological dead space (due to poor ventilation) or poor gas diffusion and is not characterized by cardiac findings such as this patient's right ventricle heave, wide splitting S2, or loud P2. Extrapulmonary right-to-left shunting occurs in patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease or acyanotic disease with Eisenmenger's phenomenon. As with this patient, these shunts are characterized by breathlessness and fatigue. However, this patient's progressive onset, age, and lack of murmur do not suggest a heart defect, making this answer unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased left ventricular (LV) preload is not seen in patients with pulmonary hypertension. On the contrary, a decreased LV preload can occur in the late stages of pulmonary hypertension as a result of interventricular dependence causing structural alteration to the LV and decreased end-diastolic filling. Increased LV preload is seen in patients with hypervolemia, LV failure, mitral regurgitation, aortic regurgitation, and LV outflow defects, any of which may cause breathlessness. However, the lack of a heart murmur in this patient makes valve defects unlikely. Both hypervolemia and LV failure are also unlikely as this patient does not have edema, raised JVP, or any underlying predisposing factors.

D) CORRECT:

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (idiopathic/familial) leads to a rise in RV afterload because the RV must work harder to eject blood during systole. Over time, this effect can lead to RV myocardial dysfunction (cor pulmonale). The increased afterload prevents adequate pumping of blood from the RV and delays the closure of the pulmonary valve, resulting in a wide or fixed split S2. Furthermore, the increased diastolic pressure within the pulmonary artery leads to increased velocity of pulmonary valve closure, resulting in a loud P2.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypertension does not change left ventricular (LV) afterload because this condition does not increase the work required by the LV to pump blood during systole. Systemic hypertension increases LV afterload, which can cause exertional chest pain, fatigue, breathlessness, and a loud S2 (due to loud A2). However, hypertension and increased LV afterload would lead to a loud heart sound in the aortic area (2nd right intercostal space). LV outflow obstructions including aortic stenosis and hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy can also present with signs of LV afterload. However, a heart murmur and possibly a history of syncope would be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

There is minor, if any, left-to-right shunting in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Left-to-right shunting occurs in patients with ventricular septal defects and atrial septal defects, and is characterized symptomatically by breathlessness and fatigue. This patient's progressive onset, age, and lack of murmur do not suggest a heart defect, making this answer unlikely.
questions.hint: This middle-aged patient presents with dyspnea, signs of right ventricular (RV) hypertrophy (right ventricle heave, chest pain), and signs of pulmonary hypertension (wide splitting S2, loud P2). Coupled with her positive family history, this presentation is highly suggestive of familial pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressive fatigue and exertional dyspnea. Cardiac examination shows a loud S2 in the 2nd left intercostal space. Right heart catheterization shows a pulmonary artery pressure of 32 mm Hg. Treatment with bosentan is initiated. The beneficial effect of this drug is due to binding to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium channel blocking agents (e.g., nifedipine) can block L-type voltage-gated calcium channels. While this type of agent can be used to treat pulmonary artery hypertension, bosentan has a different mechanism of action.

B) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil) prevent the degradation of cGMP, which normally promotes vasodilation and relaxation of smooth muscles. Although phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors can be used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension, bosentan has a different mechanism of action.
Image Description:

Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostacyclin analogs (e.g., iloprost) have an agonist effect on the prostacyclin receptor. Prostacyclin is a potent vasodilator with antiplatelet effects. Although prostacyclin receptors can be administered in pulmonary arterial hypertension, bosentan has a different mechanism of action.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenosine is a drug commonly used to terminate supraventricular tachycardia because it hyperpolarizes the AV node by increasing potassium conductance. Adenosine receptor antagonists (e.g., methylxanthines) induce smooth muscle relaxation and bronchodilation and are therefore used in the treatment of asthma. Bosentan, however, does not bind to the adenosine receptor.

E) CORRECT:

Endothelin receptor antagonists (e.g., bosentan) competitively antagonize endothelin-1 receptors. Endothelin normally promotes vasoconstriction and can increase resistance in pulmonary vessels, leading to pulmonary arterial hypertension. Targeting the endothelin receptor, therefore, prevents pulmonary vasoconstriction.
questions.hint: The target of this drug also plays an important role in hemostasis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. Her paternal uncle had similar symptoms and died of respiratory failure at 45 years of age. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Pulmonary function testing shows an FVC of 84%, an FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%, and a normal diffusion capacity. An ECG shows a QRS axis greater than +90 degrees. Genetic analysis shows an inactivating mutation in the bone morphogenetic protein receptor type II (BMPR2) gene. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic intravascular hemolysis can also cause dyspnea and fatigue due to anemia. Intravascular hemolysis may be due to organic (e.g., sickle cell disease, beta-thalassemia, spherocytosis) or mechanical causes (e.g., aortic stenosis, prosthetic heart valves). However, a right axis deviation would not be expected on ECG, and the BMPR2 gene mutation is not associated with hemolytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with chronic lung disorders (e.g., COPD, interstitial lung diseases) or chronic hypoxemia, sustained hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction causes vascular remodeling and can lead to pulmonary hypertension (PH), which can also manifest with dyspnea and fatigue as well as a right axis deviation on ECG. However, the BMPR2 gene mutation is not associated with hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and her symptoms are most likely due to a different cause.

C) INCORRECT:

An elevated left atrial pressure would be consistent with mitral stenosis or left heart failure, both of which can cause pulmonary edema, which can manifest with dyspnea and fatigue. However, pulmonary edema would cause bilateral basilar rales on auscultation and other findings of heart failure, such as orthopnea, would also be expected. This patient's BMPR2 gene mutation makes a different cause more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis decreases the capacity for oxygen diffusion in the lungs and can also cause severe dyspnea and fatigue. The etiology of fibrosis of the pulmonary parenchyma may be primary (idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis) or secondary (e.g., hypersensitivity pneumonitis). However, this patient's normal DLCO and BMPR2 gene mutation make pulmonary fibrosis very unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Thickening of the interventricular septum is most commonly seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a hereditary disease associated with sarcomeric mutations. Dyspnea and fatigue may occur as a result of heart failure due to the decreased filling of the hypertrophied ventricles and pulmonary vascular congestion. However, an ECG of a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy would show prominent left axis deviation rather than the right axis deviation seen in this patient. Moreover, the BMPR2 gene mutation is not associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

F) CORRECT:

The patient's positive family history and BMPR2 mutation suggest hereditary pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) causing her symptoms of dyspnea and fatigue. The BMPR2 gene mutation is an autosomal dominant trait that is thought to cause excessive endothelial cell proliferation in response to injury. This hyperproliferation results in vessel narrowing and increased pulmonary vascular resistance, leading to pulmonary hypertension. A right axis deviation on ECG is suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy and is considered specific for PAH when coupled with other PAH risk factors (e.g., family history).
questions.hint: Treatment with an endothelin receptor antagonist (bosentan) would be considered in a patient with dyspnea, right axis deviation on ECG (QRS axis greater than +90 degrees), and a BMPR2 mutation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past 4 months. Initially, his symptoms occurred only while climbing stairs, but now they are also present at rest. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. He was diagnosed with gastric cancer 11 months ago and was treated with chemotherapy and surgery. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. His respirations are 22/min; other vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination shows a well-healed midline laparotomy scar, jugular venous distension, mild hepatomegaly, and bilateral 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. Cardiac examination shows a loud P2 and a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur best heard in the fourth left intercostal space near the sternal border. Bruits that become louder with inspiration are heard diffusely over both lung fields. Serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows enlargement of the central pulmonary trunk, a prominent right heart border, and decreased vascular markings. Echocardiography shows dilation and hypertrophy of the right ventricle, dilation of the right atrium, and regurgitant flow across the tricuspid valve during systole. Spirometry shows no abnormalities. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg at rest (N = 10–20) and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg (N = 5–16). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's cardiac catheterization findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary proliferative vasculopathy is a cause of PH (specifically pulmonary arterial hypertension) and right heart failure. However, this condition typically manifests in young adults. Malignancy and recent surgery in this older patient with bruits over the lung fields make another diagnosis more likely.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), which can manifest with cor pulmonale. CTEPH can result from single or recurrent episodes of pulmonary embolism and should be suspected when pulmonary hypertension (PH) is diagnosed, especially in patients with risk factors for venous thromboembolism (e.g., malignancy, recent surgery). Decreased vascular markings on chest x-ray (i.e., Westermark sign) and bruits over the lung fields (i.e., flow murmurs over obstructed lung vessels) indicate diffuse pulmonary hypoperfusion and are characteristic of CTEPH. V/Q scan should be performed to differentiate CTEPH from pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), the two most likely diagnoses in this setting. Although this patient directly underwent right heart catheterization, this study is usually performed along with pulmonary angiography to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment of CTEPH involves life-long anticoagulation and pulmonary thromboendarterectomy in suitable patients.

The causes of pulmonary hypertension can be classified into five groups: (1) idiopathic or hereditary, (2) left-sided heart disease, (3) chronic hypoxic lung disease, (4) chronic thromboembolism, and (5) unclear multifactorial mechanisms (e.g., sarcoidosis, metabolic disease, chronic hemolytic anemia).

C) INCORRECT:

Serotonin-producing (e.g., carcinoid) tumors that metastasize to the liver or are located in the lung can induce carcinoid syndrome, which can manifest with shortness of breath (due to bronchospasm) and right-sided heart valve disease (e.g., tricuspid insufficiency). Carcinoids can arise from the stomach but most commonly appear in the small intestine and appendix. Although carcinoid heart disease may cause pulmonary stenosis, pulmonary hypertension is a rare manifestation. Moreover, this patient lacks other symptoms characteristic of carcinoid syndrome (e.g., diarrhea, flushing).

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction is the cause of PH and cor pulmonale in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and chronic lung diseases such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and interstitial lung disease (ILD). Chemotherapy regimens for gastric cancer may include taxanes (e.g., docetaxel), which can induce pulmonary fibrosis, a type of ILD. However, these etiologies are unlikely in this patient who is a nonsmoker, not obese, has normal oxygen saturation and spirometry results, and lacks evidence of lung parenchymal disease on chest x-ray. This patient's malignancy, recent surgery, and bruits over the lung fields make another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapy-induced dilated cardiomyopathy can be caused by anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin), which are commonly used to treat gastric cancer. Affected individuals present with worsening dyspnea. However, left ventricular systolic dysfunction is often present, and symptomatic patients tend to have reduced ejection fraction, which is not consistent with the normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, absence of pulmonary edema on chest x-ray, and absence of left ventricular dilation on echocardiography in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features (pedal edema, jugular venous distention, tricuspid regurgitation, loud P2) and cardiac catheterization findings (increased mean pulmonary arterial pressure) indicate that the patient has developed pulmonary hypertension (PH) and right heart failure, (i.e., cor pulmonale), without left heart failure (normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening fatigue and swelling of his legs. He has had occasional exertional chest pain and shortness of breath over the past year but has not seen a physician. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years but currently smokes only four to five cigarettes daily. His medications include inhaled daily budesonide, formoterol, and tiotropium. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air discloses an oxygen saturation of 87%. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, mild cyanosis, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Lung auscultation shows a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Cardiac examination shows a loud P2 and a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard in the fourth intercostal space at the left sternal border. In addition to smoking cessation, which of the following is most effective to improve this patient’s life expectancy?

choices.text: Positive airway pressure therapy at night

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) and smoking cessation are the interventions with the greatest impact on survival in patients with COPD. LTOT reduces hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and therefore lowers the risk of developing (or worsening) pulmonary hypertension. LTOT is indicated in patients with PaO2 ≤ 55 mm Hg or SaO2 ≤ 88% at rest despite optimal medication, and in those with a PaO2 of 55–60 mm Hg if there is evidence of pulmonary hypertension, congestive heart failure, or polycythemia. The target range of oxygen saturation should be 90–92% to reduce the risk of developing adverse effects from oxygen therapy, e.g., O2-induced hypercapnia.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumococcal vaccination reduces the incidence of community-acquired pneumonia and invasive pneumococcal diseases in patients with COPD. Together with the annual influenza vaccination, it is recommended in all patients with COPD. Both vaccinations can help reduce exacerbations, as infections are a common cause of exacerbations in COPD. Although these vaccinations prevent complications of COPD, there is a different intervention that is proven to prolong survival in patients with COPD.

C) INCORRECT:

Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor that is commonly used to treat erectile dysfunction. It is also used as pulmonary vasodilator therapy in vasoreactive forms of PH to decrease pulmonary vascular resistance. However, this therapy aims to mitigate the symptoms of PH and has not been shown to prolong survival in patients with COPD.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory physiotherapy and pulmonary rehabilitation (e.g., breathing exercises such as pursed lip breathing) can improve pulmonary function, decrease symptoms of COPD, and decrease the risk of hospitalization. However, respiratory physiotherapy does not prolong survival in COPD patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV) uses positive air pressure to keep airways open and support breathing. Long-term nocturnal NIPPV is indicated in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and can also be useful in patients with COPD who also have OSA and/or chronic hypercapnia. It is used for the treatment of acute respiratory distress in patients with, e.g., acute COPD exacerbation, severe pneumonia, and cardiogenic pulmonary edema. However, this patient has no history of OSA and NIPPV has not been shown to prolong survival in patients with isolated COPD.
questions.hint: This patient's hypoxemia, signs and symptoms of right heart failure (i.e., jugular venous distension, peripheral edema, loud P2,, tricuspid regurgitation), and history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are highly suggestive of pulmonary hypertension (PH) and cor pulmonale.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive swelling of her legs, shortness of breath on exertion, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months. She has also had nausea and decreased appetite, resulting in a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. She is being treated with paclitaxel for ovarian cancer and has had 2 episodes of pulmonary embolism during the past year. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. She appears tired. The patient is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (119 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival icterus, protuberant abdomen with a fluid wave and shifting dullness, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is visible distention of the jugular veins. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer is a risk factor for liver metastases, which can, in some cases, manifest with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension, ascites, jaundice) and/or peripheral edema if part of the hepatic venous system is compressed. In the majority of cases, however, liver metastases are asymptomatic. Moreover, they do not explain this patient's JVD.

B) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of paclitaxel include hepatotoxicity, peripheral edema, and nausea. However, paclitaxel-associated hepatotoxicity is usually limited to asymptomatic elevations of serum aminotransferases; jaundice and ascites are not common. Moreover, the toxicity profile of paclitaxel does not explain this patient's JVD.

C) CORRECT:

Signs of systemic venous congestion (JVD and bilateral lower extremity edema) and reduced right heart output (dyspnea on exertion with clear lungs on auscultation) are consistent with right heart failure. This patient's right ventricular failure is likely due to recurrent malignancy-associated pulmonary embolism, which leads to an increase in pulmonary artery pressure and right ventricular afterload. Over time, this increased ventricular afterload induces right heart remodeling with consequent right ventricular dysfunction. In severe cases, patients may also develop features of hepatic congestion (e.g., abdominal distention, jaundice, and ascites) and/or gastric congestion (e.g., nausea and early satiety). Management of decompensated right heart failure includes oxygen therapy (if the patient is hypoxemic), fluid restriction, diuretic therapy, and treatment of any underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis manifests with peripheral edema, nausea, early satiety, jaundice, abdominal pain, and ascites. Cirrhosis does not, however, explain this patient's JVD. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic findings of cirrhosis (e.g., telangiectasia, caput medusae). In addition, this patient has no known risk factors for cirrhosis (e.g., history of significant alcohol use, obesity, chronic hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome manifests with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension, ascites, jaundice), and this patient's history of ovarian cancer increases the risk of developing this condition (due to cancer-associated hypercoagulability). Budd-Chiari syndrome does not, however, explain this patient's jugular distension.
Image Description:

Budd-Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow obstruction, most commonly caused by the occlusion or partial occlusion of at least two major hepatic veins (e.g., due to thrombosis).

The subsequent hepatic venous congestion leads to increased sinusoidal pressure, cellular hypoxia, and centrilobular necrosis, resulting in hepatomegaly and, eventually, a nutmeg liver.
questions.hint: If left untreated, this patient would also develop jugular venous distention (JVD) with inspiration or deep palpation of the right upper quadrant.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma reports a 6-month history of progressively worsening dyspnea.
On examination, she has an accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and a diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border that is graded 2 on a scale of 1 to 4. She has jugular venous distention to 10 cm and 1+ lower-extremity edema. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Scleroderma is one of the more common connective tissue diseases to result in pulmonary arterial hypertension, in which there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance, with subsequent hypertrophy of the right ventricle. Cardiac examination findings characteristic of pulmonary arterial hypertension include an accentuated P2 heart sound (related to the forceful closure of the pulmonic valve), a right ventricular heave (related to right ventricular hypertrophy), and elevated right heart filling pressures. The diastolic murmur of pulmonic regurgitation (a so-called Graham Steell murmur) may also be audible, as in this patient.

Key learning point: An accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and evidence of right heart failure are most consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus would produce a continuous, machinery-like murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., right-to-left intracardiac shunting, cyanosis, and polycythemia) is caused by pulmonary hypertension related to a congenital defect between the right and left heart circulations. Scleroderma does not cause Eisenmenger syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is most often a congenital condition that produces a systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. The P2 component is usually soft, not accentuated.

E) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by elevated jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, and a pericardial knock. An accentuated P2 heart sound or a right ventricular heave is not characteristic of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with long-standing beta-thalassemia intermedia reports 3 to 4 weeks of progressive dyspnea on exertion. He states that he has not experienced cough, fevers, or chest pain. He is chronically anemic but has not required transfusions. His only other complication was a leg ulcer one year ago.
The patient’s vital signs are within normal limits, except for a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 88% while he is breathing ambient air. His heart sounds are difficult to discern because of body habitus, but his lungs are clear to auscultation. He does not have lower-extremity edema.
Laboratory testing identifies a hemoglobin level of 7.1 g/dL (reference range, 13.5–17.5) and a hematocrit of 21.0% (41.0–53.0), similar to measurements 6 months earlier.
A chest radiograph reveals normal lung volumes without parenchymal opacities or pleural effusion.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A nuclear stress test is not indicated when the likelihood of coronary artery disease is low, as it is in a patient this young.

B) INCORRECT:

CT is required for diagnosis of interstitial lung disease, but a 25-year-old patient is much more likely to have pulmonary hypertension than interstitial lung disease. In addition, interstitial lung disease severe enough to cause hypoxemia would likely be apparent in some way (opacities or low lung volumes) on chest radiograph.

C) INCORRECT:

An electrocardiogram could show a right-axis deviation and evidence of right ventricular hypertrophy to suggest the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, but it is both insensitive and nonspecific for this condition.

D) CORRECT:

A patient with a symptomatic hemoglobinopathy (“intermedia” implies symptomatic), especially sickle cell disease, alpha-thalassemia, or beta-thalassemia, is at risk for pulmonary arterial hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension is one of the most common causes of death in patients with this condition.

A transthoracic echocardiogram is the test of choice for diagnosing pulmonary hypertension.

Key learning point: The most common complication of beta-thalassemia intermedia is pulmonary hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing may help to diagnose underlying airflow limitation or restriction, but such testing is not the first step of evaluation in the setting of normal auscultation (i.e., no wheezes or crackles) and a chest radiograph with normal lung volumes and without parenchymal abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a one-year history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and light-headedness while walking up stairs. She has no known medical problems and takes no medications. She has never smoked cigarettes but reports heavy use of both alcohol and methamphetamine for approximately 10 years, until about 15 years ago.
On examination, she has a 3/6 systolic murmur most audible at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration, a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound, clear lungs, and 1+ bilateral edema of the lower extremities.
What additional finding would you expect to hear on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: An S4 gallop audible at the apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position
An S3 gallop audible over the left sternal border with the patient lying supine
A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur audible over the upper right sternal border
An S3 gallop audible at the apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position
A rumbling diastolic murmur audible at the apex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left-sided gallops are best heard with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position and listening at the apex. Extra sounds that are heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position are most typically associated with diseases affecting the left ventricle.

B) CORRECT:

In a patient with clear lungs, the findings of a 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. The remote history of methamphetamine use is a risk factor for the development of pulmonary hypertension.

Pulmonary hypertension is often associated with a right-sided S3 or S4 gallop. To confirm this heart sound, it is optimal to ask the patient to lie supine and inspire and then to auscultate over the left sternal border.

Right-sided systolic murmurs and gallops tend to become louder with inspiration, owing to increased right ventricular filling. Because the right ventricle is the most anterior cardiac chamber, positioning patients supinely and listening at the left sternal border helps distinguish right-sided sounds from those emanating from the laterally placed left ventricle.

Key learning point: In addition to a systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound, the heart sound most typical of pulmonary hypertension is a right-sided S3 or S4 gallop.

C) INCORRECT:

A systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur is most typical of aortic stenosis. Neither mitral nor aortic stenosis is typically seen in patients with methamphetamine-induced pulmonary hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Left-sided gallops are best heard with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position and listening at the apex. Extra sounds that are heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position are most typically associated with diseases affecting the left ventricle.

E) INCORRECT:

A rumbling diastolic murmur at the apex is most typical of mitral stenosis. Neither mitral nor aortic stenosis is typically seen in patients with methamphetamine-induced pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman reports 5 months of progressive dyspnea on exertion. She used to be able to jog 3 miles without difficulty. Now, she can only walk one mile and at a much slower pace than before. Her history is significant for a provoked pulmonary embolism 2 years ago, after a hysterectomy for abnormal uterine bleeding; the embolism was treated with anticoagulation. The patient is not currently taking any medications.
Her vital signs include a blood pressure of 110/80 mm Hg, a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 90% while she is breathing ambient air.
Physical examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure, a loud P2 heart sound, and a heave at the left sternal border. Her lungs are clear on auscultation. She has 2+ peripheral edema up to the knees.
Diagnostic workup reveals an extensive chronic thrombus within the proximal right main pulmonary artery and mosaic attenuation on CT pulmonary angiography, a dilated right ventricle with reduced systolic function on transthoracic echocardiogram, and a right ventricular systolic pressure of 56 mm Hg.
After initiating therapeutic anticoagulation, which one of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tissue plasminogen activator is not indicated without evidence of acute, hemodynamically significant pulmonary embolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Medical therapy with a pulmonary vasodilator, such as riociguat, sildenafil, or bosentan, should be reserved for patients who are not appropriate candidates for surgery, as outcomes are clearly better with surgical intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Medical therapy with a pulmonary vasodilator, such as riociguat, sildenafil, or bosentan, should be reserved for patients who are not appropriate candidates for surgery, as outcomes are clearly better with surgical intervention. The data for use of these agents in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension are limited but best for riociguat.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension is a complication experienced by 2% to 4% of patients after acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Many patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension exhibit subtle symptoms without a history of overt PE. Physical examination typically reveals signs of elevated right ventricular pressure with corresponding echocardiographic findings. The preferred diagnostic strategy is either ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography.

For suspected chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) with a proximal and accessible clot burden, systemic anticoagulation should be initiated, and the patient should be referred for evaluation by a center experienced in pulmonary thromboendarterectomy, as this procedure is associated with dramatic improvements in symptoms and functional status.

Key learning point: The preferred therapeutic option for a patient with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension is referral for pulmonary thromboendarterectomy.

E) INCORRECT:

Medical therapy with a pulmonary vasodilator, such as riociguat, sildenafil, or bosentan, should be reserved for patients who are not appropriate candidates for surgery, as outcomes are clearly better with surgical intervention.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman reports 8 months of slowly progressive dyspnea on exertion, leaving her unable to walk more than one block without resting. She also describes several recent presyncopal episodes related to exertion. She says she has no chest pain.
On physical examination, she has a blood pressure of 110/82 mm Hg, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 94% while she is breathing ambient air. Her jugular venous pressure is 5 cm above the clavicle with a prominent V-wave. Cardiac auscultation reveals a prominent second heart sound over the left-upper sternal border. Both lungs are clear on auscultation. Trace pedal edema is evident.
The patient’s laboratory tests show normal levels of blood urea nitrogen and creatinine. Her pulmonary function tests show normal spirometry, but the diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide is 60% of predicted (normal >80%). Echocardiography reveals 3+ tricuspid regurgitation and an estimated right ventricular systolic pressure of 62 mm Hg (<35 mm Hg). Left ventricular function is normal.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following studies is indicated to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Without a clinical history or other evidence to suggest acute or chronic pulmonary embolism, a pulmonary angiogram, ventilation-perfusion scan, or cardiac MRI would be of little help in establishing a diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Without a clinical history or other evidence to suggest acute or chronic pulmonary embolism, a pulmonary angiogram, ventilation-perfusion scan, or cardiac MRI would be of little help in establishing a diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Pulmonary hypertension can be a primary diagnosis, or it may be secondary to any of a myriad of other disease states. The associated symptoms are nonspecific, so the average delay from symptom onset to diagnosis is 2 years. Elevated jugular venous pressure, a prominent P2 second heart sound on auscultation, and isolated reduction in diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide together suggest pulmonary hypertension. The first step is usually an echocardiogram to noninvasively assess for elevated right-sided pressures. However, right heart catheterization is required to establish or rule out the diagnosis. It also helps to evaluate right ventricular function, to assess for intracardiac shunt, and (if an appropriate diagnosis is established) to guide therapy.

Key learning point: Diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension requires demonstration of elevated pulmonary pressures (mean pulmonary artery pressure >20 mm Hg) on right heart catheterization.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypertension can be a primary diagnosis, or it may be secondary to any of a myriad of other disease states. The associated symptoms are nonspecific, so the average delay from symptom onset to diagnosis is 2 years. Elevated jugular venous pressure, a prominent P2 second heart sound on auscultation, and isolated reduction in diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide together suggest pulmonary hypertension. The first step is usually an echocardiogram to noninvasively assess for elevated right-sided pressures. However, right heart catheterization is required to establish or rule out the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Without a clinical history or other evidence to suggest acute or chronic pulmonary embolism, a pulmonary angiogram, ventilation-perfusion scan, or cardiac MRI would be of little help in establishing a diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents for evaluation of progressive dyspnea on exertion. She is typically healthy, other than moderate gastroesophageal reflux. She states that she has no cough or chest pain. She gives a history of her fingers turning white and painful when being exposed to cold.
Her heart rate is 103 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. At rest, her oxygen saturation is 95% while she is breathing ambient air, but it falls to 89% with ambulation. Cardiac examination is notable for a fixed split second heart sound; she has mild, symmetric lower-extremity swelling. She has no wheezes or crackles. Her skin examination is notable for a few digital ulcers and thickened patches of skin over her hands and on the face, but not elsewhere.
A chest radiograph is without opacities, but the hila look prominent. A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are within normal limits. Anticentromere antibodies are positive.
Which one of the following next steps is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s dyspnea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A methacholine challenge is used to diagnose asthma, which is unlikely in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Ventilation-perfusion imaging is often used in the workup after pulmonary hypertension has been confirmed, specifically to identify chronic thromboembolic disease.

C) CORRECT:

This patient likely has limited systemic sclerosis (SSc, scleroderma), given her history of esophageal disease (gastroesophageal reflux), severe Raynaud phenomenon (with digital ulcerations), and sclerodactyly. These features, along with telangiectasia and calcinosis cutis, make up the CREST features classically seen in patients with the limited variant of SSc. These patients also tend to have positive anti-centromere antibodies.

All variants of SSc are associated with the development of interstitial lung disease (ILD) as well as pulmonary arterial hypertension, but the severity of these complications typically segregates with the subtype of SSc. Limited SSc is more commonly associated with symptomatic pulmonary arterial hypertension and mild, subclinical ILD. Patients with the diffuse variant of SSc have more extensive skin involvement beyond the distal extremities and face. They are more likely to experience organ fibrosis, including severe ILD. In these patients, pulmonary arterial hypertension tends to be less severe except in the end-stages of advanced ILD.

In this patient, the presence of features of limited, rather than diffuse, SSc on physical examination makes pulmonary hypertension a more likely cause of dyspnea than interstitial fibrosis. Other features of her presentation also make pulmonary hypertension likely including ambulatory desaturation, lower-extremity edema, and a fixed split second heart sound. A chest radiograph without opacities and the absence of crackles on pulmonary auscultation make an underlying interstitial process less likely.

Echocardiography is the modality of choice during initial evaluation for pulmonary hypertension because it is noninvasive and easily obtained. Echocardiography can assess right and left ventricular function as well as systolic pulmonary artery pressure. If systolic pulmonary artery pressure is elevated, it suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, but this is not a definitive study. The next step would be a right heart catheterization, which allows the measurement of a mean pulmonary artery pressure. The diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension is made when the mean pulmonary artery pressure exceeds 20 mm Hg.

Key learning point: The best initial study to evaluate for scleroderma-related pulmonary hypertension is an echocardiogram.

D) INCORRECT:

Direct laryngoscopy would be used to evaluate suspected vocal-cord dysfunction, which is unlikely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT of the chest would be useful in identifying interstitial lung disease, which is less likely to explain this patient’s dyspnea. She has primarily limited systemic sclerosis with CREST features, and anti-centromere antibody.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with a history of hypothyroidism and two prior spontaneous abortions reports worsening dyspnea on exertion, beginning about 6 months ago. She takes levothyroxine supplementation.
Physical examination reveals an increased second pulmonary heart sound and trace lower-extremity edema. Her oxygen saturation is 95% while she is breathing ambient air and decreases to 91% with ambulation. Pulmonary function testing is normal, with the exception of a reduced diffusion capacity at 55% of predicted. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular function and estimates the pulmonary artery systolic pressure at 54 mm Hg.
Which one of the following diagnostic studies is most likely to identify a cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Noncontrast high-resolution CT scan of the thorax

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contrast CT of the chest might also be helpful in this situation, but a noncontrast CT is likely to have a low yield.

B) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas testing might help to confirm hypoxemia but also would not identify an etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiogram has a low diagnostic yield when valvular disease is not suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiopulmonary exercise testing may further increase suspicion of pulmonary hypertension if a patient has exercise-induced desaturation, but it would not help to identify a specific etiology.

E) CORRECT:

An increased second heart sound, lower-extremity edema, exercise-induced oxygen desaturation, and a reduced diffusion capacity all strongly suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. A history of hypothyroidism and antiphospholipid syndrome may increase risk for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension. An appropriate diagnostic study is a pulmonary ventilation-perfusion scan.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with features of the antiphospholipid syndrome, worsening dyspnea on exertion, and exercise-induced oxygen desaturation is chronic thromboembolic pulmonary disease with resulting pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman with long-standing HIV infection presents with worsening dyspnea during the past 3 to 4 months. Her last CD4 count was 425 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600), and she has an undetectable viral load on her antiretroviral therapy. She has not had fevers, significant cough, or wheezing, but has had some mild pleuritic chest pain.
She is a thin woman in no distress. She is afebrile and has an oxygen saturation of 92% while she is breathing ambient air. Both lungs are clear, and her cardiac examination is notable for a prominent second heart sound. She has trace symmetric lower-extremity edema.
A chest radiograph is without opacities. Her leukocyte count is 6000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000). Her spirometry and lung volumes are normal, but her diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide is 65% of predicted.
Which one of the following diagnostic studies is most appropriate to evaluate this patient's dyspnea?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with long-standing HIV infection are at higher risk of developing pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). PAH classically manifests with a prominent second heart sound and a reduced diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide in the setting of normal spirometry and lung volumes.

An echocardiogram is the best study to assess for possible PAH; the diagnosis is confirmed with right heart catheterization.

Key learning point: Normal spirometry and lung volumes with a decreased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide in a patient with long-standing HIV infection warrant investigation for pulmonary arterial hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Although CT of the chest and sputum or blood cultures may be helpful in evaluating for opportunistic infections, these would not be appropriate next steps in the setting of a chest radiograph without opacities and the pattern of normal lung volumes with a decreased capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide. The progressive nature of her dyspnea over several months makes acute pulmonary embolism unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient may eventually need a ventilation-perfusion scan to evaluate for other causes of PAH, but this study would be appropriate after echocardiogram and right heart catheterization have confirmed the diagnosis of PAH.

D) INCORRECT:

Although CT of the chest and sputum or blood cultures may be helpful in evaluating for opportunistic infections, these would not be appropriate next steps in the setting of a chest radiograph without opacities and the pattern of normal lung volumes with a decreased capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide. The progressive nature of her dyspnea over several months makes acute pulmonary embolism unlikely.

The patient may eventually need a CT of the chest to evaluate for other causes of PAH, but this study would be appropriate after echocardiogram and right heart catheterization have confirmed the diagnosis of PAH.

E) INCORRECT:

Induced sputum is an appropriate test for a patient in whom Pneumocystis pneumonia is a concern, but the risk is low in patients whose HIV infection is well controlled.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman reports a 2-month history of increasing dyspnea on exertion. While breathing ambient air, she has an oxygen saturation of 91% at rest and 84% after ambulating 200 feet (61 meters).
A chest radiograph is unremarkable. Pulmonary function testing finds no evidence of obstruction or restriction. An echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular size, a normal left ventricular ejection fraction, an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 40 mm Hg (reference range, 15–25), and no right ventricular dilation or dysfunction. A bubble study does not show evidence of interatrial shunt.
Right heart catheterization demonstrates a pulmonary artery capillary wedge pressure of 28 mm Hg (6–12) and a mean pulmonary artery pressure of 36 mm Hg (10–20).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methamphetamine use would result in an elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure with a normal pulmonary artery capillary wedge pressure.

B) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is a valuable screening tool when there is clinical suspicion for pulmonary hypertension; however, it is unable to distinguish pulmonary arterial hypertension from pulmonary venous hypertension. Right heart catheterization is often necessary to confirm a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension and to distinguish between these two conditions.
