When the mean pulmonary artery pressure is > 20 mm Hg (reference range, 10 - 20) and the pulmonary artery capillary wedge pressure is < 15 mm Hg (6 - 12), pulmonary arterial hypertension is diagnosed. If the capillary wedge pressure is > 15 mm Hg, the cause of the pulmonary hypertension is an elevated pulmonary venous pressure. The most common cause of pulmonary venous hypertension is left heart failure, which can be from either systolic or diastolic dysfunction.

Approximately 83% of patients who have heart failure with preserved ejection fraction have an elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure; therefore, this is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

Key learning point: An elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure with an elevated pulmonary artery capillary wedge pressure indicates pulmonary venous hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Sickle cell disease would result in an elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure with a normal pulmonary artery capillary wedge pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Obstructive sleep apnea would result in an elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure with a normal pulmonary artery capillary wedge pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic thromboembolic disease would result in an elevated mean pulmonary artery pressure with a normal pulmonary artery capillary wedge pressure.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man reports a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea, intermittent chest pain, and fatigue. He has long-standing HIV infection and has never taken antiretroviral therapy; his most recent CD4 count was 310 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600).
On examination, he is afebrile and normotensive. He has a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 90% while breathing ambient air.
His cardiac examination reveals an accentuated second heart sound and a jugular venous pressure of 10 cm of water. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and he has 2+ bilateral lower-extremity edema to his midthigh. His chest radiograph shows clear lung fields.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate in the evaluation of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Pulmonary function testing with measurement of diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide
Direct fluorescence antibody testing of induced sputum for Pneumocystis jirovecii

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In people with HIV, evidence of right heart failure with a loud second heart sound raises the suspicion for pulmonary arterial hypertension, which should be evaluated initially with a transthoracic echocardiogram. The reported incidence of pulmonary arterial hypertension in people with HIV is 0.5% in population studies; no direct relationship to CD4-cell count appears to exist.

Key learning point: A patient with HIV infection who develops dyspnea and a loud second heart sound should be evaluated for pulmonary hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests are appropriate for evaluation for obstructive or restrictive lung disease, neither of which is suggested here. An isolated reduced diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide would suggest pulmonary vascular disease but would not help to specifically diagnose pulmonary hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase testing and direct fluorescence antibody testing of respiratory secretions may be indicated to evaluate for Pneumocystis jirovecii, but this diagnosis is unlikely in a patient with a CD4 count >200 cells per mm3, no constitutional symptoms, and chest radiograph without opacities.

D) INCORRECT:

The chronicity of the patient’s clinical presentation and physical examination would be unusual for acute pulmonary embolism, so D-dimer is not the best test.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase testing and direct fluorescence antibody testing of respiratory secretions may be indicated to evaluate for Pneumocystis jirovecii, but this diagnosis is unlikely in a patient with a CD4 count >200 cells per mm3, no constitutional symptoms, and chest radiograph without opacities.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents at a follow-up visit for limited systemic sclerosis, which was diagnosed 3 years ago. A previous serologic workup was notable for a positive anticentromere antibody result. The patient takes maximum-dose nifedipine for Raynaud phenomenon. She now complains, for the first time, of increased shortness of breath and decreased exercise tolerance.
Her physical examination is notable for cachexia, scattered telangiectasia, and skin tightness involving the fingers and face. She has acrocyanosis of the digits and evidence of old (healed) digital ulcerations in several fingers. Her cardiac examination reveals a loud second heart sound and a right ventricular heave. The lungs sound clear on bilateral auscultation. Echocardiography was attempted but nondiagnostic for technical reasons.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with a bronchodilator and a high-dose glucocorticoid
Refer the patient for lung-transplant evaluation
Refer the patient for right heart catheterization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are not thought to be effective in treating pulmonary arterial hypertension. In addition, treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids should be avoided in patients with systemic sclerosis, as it may precipitate scleroderma renal crisis, particularly in patients with rapidly progressive cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyclophosphamide is a treatment option for interstitial lung disease, with clinical trials showing a modest benefit, but there is no strong evidence for its effectiveness in pulmonary arterial hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, which can be used to treat Raynaud phenomenon, is ineffective for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension in the vast majority of patients with systemic sclerosis. In this particular case, the patient is symptomatic despite already being on a maximum dose of nifedipine.

D) INCORRECT:

Lung transplantation is reserved for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension who have failed to respond to medical therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance in a patient with systemic sclerosis suggests pulmonary involvement. All patients with systemic sclerosis should be screened for interstitial lung disease (ILD) and pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Physical examination findings of a loud second (S2) heart sound and right ventricular heave are more consistent with PAH. Also, patients with limited systemic sclerosis and a positive anticentromere antibody result are more likely to develop PAH than ILD.

Patients with suspected PAH should be referred to a pulmonary hypertension specialist or clinic for right heart catheterization to confirm the diagnosis. Vasoreactivity testing during the procedure may assist with treatment selection. Reactivity testing is performed during right heart catheterization and assesses the response of the pulmonary arterial pressure (PAP) to inhaled nitric oxide or another vasodilator; a positive response is defined as a reduction in mean PAP of ≥10 mm Hg to reach an absolute value of ≤40 mm Hg, with increased or unchanged cardiac output. If there is a positive response, then the patient may respond favorably to high-dose oral calcium-channel blockers, which are less expensive and better tolerated than alternative therapies.

If the vasoreactivity test is negative, or if high-dose calcium-channel blockers are ineffective, then alternative treatments such as prostacyclin pathway agonists, endothelin receptor antagonists, or phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors can be considered. This particular patient, who has PAH associated with connective tissue disease, has a low probability of having a positive vasoreactivity test. Some experts may therefore choose to omit this step and proceed directly to more advanced therapies.

Key learning point: Patients with systemic sclerosis are at increased risk for pulmonary complications of interstitial lung disease and pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a history of cigarette smoking presents for evaluation of worsening dyspnea. He has had mild shortness of breath on exertion for the past 3 years, but it has worsened substantially in the past month. He has a chronic productive cough but has not noticed any recent changes in the quantity or quality of the sputum. He has had new-onset leg swelling in the past few weeks.
He is afebrile and has a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/85 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 88% while breathing ambient air. His breath sounds are distant with a few faint wheezes. He has a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound. His jugular venous pressure appears elevated, and he has significant bilateral lower-extremity edema.
A chest radiograph reveals cardiomegaly, enlarged central pulmonary arteries, and hyperinflated lungs. There is no evidence of infiltrative processes.
An electrocardiogram shows a right bundle-branch block and right axis deviation.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely to explain this patient’s worsening dyspnea?

choices.text: Exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A COPD exacerbation is a consideration in this patient given his productive cough and wheeze, but he does not report a change in the quantity or quality of his sputum, and a COPD exacerbation alone would not explain his other examination findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumonia can manifest atypically, but this patient has no findings to suggest acute infection (e.g., fever, change in sputum production, or opacity on chest radiograph).

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's obesity and history of cigarette smoking put him at risk for cardiac ischemia and for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, these diagnoses are less likely given the physical and electrocardiographic findings consistent with right ventricular pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's obesity and history of cigarette smoking put him at risk for cardiac ischemia and for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, these diagnoses are less likely given the physical and electrocardiographic findings consistent with right ventricular pathology.

E) CORRECT:

This patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has cor pulmonale that is secondary to pulmonary hypertension. He has electrocardiographic evidence of right ventricular pathology (right bundle-branch block and right axis deviation) and evidence of right-sided heart failure on examination (elevated jugular venous pressure, lower-extremity edema, tricuspid regurgitation). The loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound and radiographic evidence of enlarged central pulmonary arteries also support the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale. COPD is the most common cause of pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale in the United States.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, worsening dyspnea, and signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure is pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents for outpatient follow-up one month after a hospitalization for prolonged, progressive dyspnea.
During that admission, a comprehensive history revealed no prior health problems, no evidence of obstructive sleep apnea or connective tissue disease, and no prior use of tobacco, illicit drugs, or over-the-counter weight-loss pills. Physical examination was notable for a prominent pulmonic component of the second heart sound and mild lower-extremity edema. She was not hypoxemic. Evaluation was negative for connective tissue disease and HIV infection.
A chest radiograph during the admission revealed prominent hila bilaterally. An echocardiogram showed normal left ventricular and valve function but an elevated right ventricular systolic pressure. A ventilation-perfusion scan demonstrated low probability for thromboembolism. Right heart catheterization revealed normal cardiac output, a mean pulmonary artery pressure of 35 mm Hg (reference range, 8–20), and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg (6–12). Administration of inhaled nitric oxide during catheterization did not improve the pulmonary hemodynamics. Sildenafil therapy three times daily was initiated.
During today’s follow-up visit, the patient says she is tolerating the sildenafil well and reports improvement in her symptoms. However, she still experiences mild dyspnea when climbing stairs or rushing to the bus. She performs her daily activities without significant discomfort but notes she is not her “normal self.”
Which one of the following additional treatments is most likely to improve this patient’s quality of life?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Riociguat is a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulant that, like PDE-5 inhibitors, acts as a pulmonary vasodilator by prolonging the effect of nitric oxide. Because of these similar mechanisms, the combination of riociguat and PDE-5 inhibitors should be avoided, as there is increased risk of significant hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

An oral calcium-channel blocker, such as amlodipine, nifedipine, or diltiazem, could be considered in a patient with a positive vasoreactivity test. A vasoreactivity test is performed during right heart catheterization by administering nitric oxide, epoprostenol, or adenosine. The test is deemed to be positive if the patient’s hemodynamics improve to meet certain criteria (i.e., a decrease in mean pulmonary artery pressure by 10 mm Hg to a value <40 mm Hg without a decrease in cardiac output or systemic blood pressure). A positive vasoreactivity test suggests a better overall prognosis and a favorable clinical response to oral calcium-channel blockers. This patient had a negative vasoreactivity test during right heart catheterization and should therefore not be treated with a calcium-channel blocker.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic anticoagulation with warfarin is sometimes administered in the setting of PAH, given the high prevalence of pulmonary thrombotic lesions on postmortem examinations of patients with PAH and the theory that pulmonary embolism or in-situ thrombosis may cause cardiovascular collapse by further raising pulmonary vascular resistance. However, the most recent guideline to address this topic (published in 2016) gives systemic anticoagulation in idiopathic PAH the weakest recommendation, stating that it “may be considered on an individual basis.” There is stronger evidence that combination pulmonary vasodilator therapy would improve this patient’s quality of life. Notably, in patients with PAH secondary to connective tissue disease, systemic anticoagulation is associated with increased mortality risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous epoprostenol, a prostanoid that acts through the prostacyclin pathway, is reserved for patients who are in NYHA functional class IV (symptoms at rest) or class III (marked limitations on daily life) and who have rapidly progressing symptoms. The use of intravenous epoprostenol requires intense monitoring and lifestyle changes that may affect quality of life; it should not be used in patients with minor symptoms who have alternative therapy options.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical history is consistent with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) or World Health Organization (WHO) group 1 pulmonary hypertension.

When evaluating patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), clinicians should assess the severity of symptoms before deciding on therapy. The New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional classification is the scale most often used for this and ranges from class I (no symptoms) to class IV (severe symptoms at rest). This patient has NYHA functional class II symptoms (minor limitations on daily life).

According to current guidelines, patients with PAH who have symptoms that persist while using a single pulmonary vasodilator medication should be treated with combination therapy that includes a second pulmonary vasodilator from a separate drug class. Combination pulmonary vasodilator therapy has been shown to improve patients’ functional classification, 6-minute walk distance, and pulmonary hemodynamics, all of which are associated with improved quality of life.

This patient currently takes sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitor that prolongs the effect of nitric oxide. A pulmonary vasodilator from the endothelin-receptor antagonist class, such as ambrisentan, would be an appropriate choice to use in combination with a PDE-5 inhibitor.

Key learning point: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension who have persistent symptoms while using a single pulmonary vasodilator medication should be treated with combination therapy that includes a second pulmonary vasodilator from a separate drug class.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 9-year-old girl reports that every morning for the past 3 months, she has become overly tired while running in gym class. After barely starting a lap around the running track, she must stop to catch her breath; she usually feels dizzy and occasionally has chest pain. Her symptoms have worsened progressively, and she is embarrassed to always finish last among her classmates. She feels better after she rests. She reports no palpitations, syncope, musculoskeletal tenderness, fevers, cough, or congestion.
On examination, she is afebrile, with a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 94/57 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. She appears thin and is in no apparent distress. Her cardiac examination is notable for a 2/6 blowing holosystolic murmur, loudest at the left lower sternal border. There is a single, loud second heart sound without respiratory variation. There are no retractions, and both lung fields are clear to auscultation. Her liver edge is 2 cm below the right costal margin. Her radial and femoral pulses are 2+ without delay, and her capillary refill time is <2 seconds. She does not have calf tenderness.
An electrocardiogram (figure 1) and chest radiograph (figure 2) are obtained.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asthma is a common cause of dyspnea on exertion in children but is unlikely in this case given the patient’s positive cardiac findings, lack of notable pulmonary findings, and lack of predisposing atopic risk factors.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with partial anomalous pulmonary venous return (PAPVR) typically present with low-pressure left-to-right shunting, with physiology similar to that of an atrial septal defect, and thus are relatively unlikely to present with heart failure or PAH at this patient’s age. Patients with PAPVR may have a wide (and perhaps fixed) splitting of the second heart sound related to increased duration of throughput across the pulmonary valve from volume loading, rather than the single, loud second heart sound in in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) should always be considered in patients with dyspnea. However, it typically manifests with acute onset of cardiorespiratory symptoms rather than the chronic presentation seen in this case. Furthermore, this patient does not have any PE risk factors, such as associated inflammatory systemic conditions, immobility, or indwelling central venous catheterization. Although PE can cause right ventricular failure, it is unusual.

D) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular systolic heart failure related to dilated cardiomyopathy can manifest with fatigue, exercise intolerance, and dyspnea on exertion, but one would expect to see evidence of pulmonary vascular congestion, such as crackles on physical examination and pulmonary edema on chest radiograph. In addition, this patient’s chest radiograph is more consistent with right ventricular enlargement, as the left ventricle does not contribute to the cardiomegaly.

E) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis for exercise intolerance and dyspnea on exertion can include both cardiac and respiratory causes, and the diagnosis often depends on correct interpretation of the cardiorespiratory examination and ancillary tests.

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) occurs when pulmonary arterial pressures are elevated due to abnormal pulmonary vascular resistance and nonelevated left atrial pressures. This condition may be genetic, idiopathic, or related to other systemic diseases. Fatigue and dyspnea on exertion are typically the initial symptoms in adults, but in children, the manifestations may be more variable and insidious, ranging from asymptomatic to dizziness and syncope to severe right heart failure. Therefore, the diagnosis of PAH in children requires a high index of suspicion and is often missed.

This patient has a single, loud second heart sound without respiratory variation, which is caused by elevated pulmonary arterial pressures that immediately lead to pulmonary valve closure in early diastole, eliminating the P2 -A2 split appreciated during inspiration in healthy patients. Many patients with PAH (although not this one) will also have an early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border, known as a Graham Steell murmur.

The elevated pulmonary pressures also account for the patient’s tricuspid insufficiency systolic blowing murmur and can lead to variable degrees of right ventricular hypertrophy, enlargement, and dysfunction as well as hepatomegaly. Her electrocardiogram (ECG) findings are consistent with compensatory right heart changes in PAH, including right axis deviation, right ventricular hypertrophy, and right atrial enlargement. Her chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly related to right heart dilation with enlargement of the main pulmonary artery that is due to elevated arterial pressures throughout the pulmonary arterial tree. Notably, the lung fields on this patient’s chest radiograph do not show parenchymal disease or pulmonary edema, which would be expected if her symptoms were related to dilated cardiomyopathy and heart failure.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a school-age child with exercise intolerance and dyspnea on exertion, a single and loud second heart sound, and a noncongested chest radiograph with enlargement of the main pulmonary artery is pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma reports a 6 month history of progressively worsening dyspnea. On examination, she has an accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and a diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border that is graded 2 on a scale of 1 to 4. She has jugular venous distention to 10 cm and 1+ lower-extremity edema. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Scleroderma is one of the more common connective tissue diseases to result in pulmonary arterial hypertension, in which there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance, with subsequent hypertrophy of the right ventricle. Cardiac examination findings characteristic of pulmonary arterial hypertension include an accentuated P2 heart sound (related to the forceful closure of the pulmonic valve), a right ventricular heave (related to right ventricular hypertrophy), and elevated right heart filling pressures. The diastolic murmur of pulmonic regurgitation (a so-called Graham Steell murmur) may also be audible, as in this patient.

Key learning point: An accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and evidence of right heart failure are most consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus would produce a continuous, machinery-like murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., right-to-left intracardiac shunting, cyanosis, and polycythemia) is caused by pulmonary hypertension related to a congenital defect between the right and left heart circulations. Scleroderma does not cause Eisenmenger syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is most often a congenital condition that produces a systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. The P2 component is usually soft, not accentuated.

E) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by elevated jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, and a pericardial knock. An accentuated P2 heart sound or a right ventricular heave is not characteristic of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a history of cigarette smoking presents for evaluation of worsening dyspnea. He has a chronic productive cough. He has an oxygen saturation of 88% while breathing ambient air, a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound. His jugular venous pressure appears elevated, and he has significant bilateral lower-extremity edema. A chest x-ray study reveals cardiomegaly, enlarged central pulmonary arteries, and hyperinflated lungs. An electrocardiogram shows a right bundle-branch block and right axis deviation. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely to explain this patient’s worsening dyspnea?

choices.text: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
Exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumonia can manifest atypically, but this patient has no findings to suggest acute infection (e.g., fever, change in sputum production, or opacity on chest radiograph).

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's obesity and history of cigarette smoking put him at risk for cardiac ischemia and for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, these diagnoses are less likely given the physical and electrocardiographic findings consistent with right ventricular pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

A COPD exacerbation is a consideration in this patient given his productive cough and wheeze, but he does not report a change in the quantity or quality of his sputum, and a COPD exacerbation alone would not explain his other examination findings.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has cor pulmonale that is secondary to pulmonary hypertension. He has electrocardiographic evidence of right ventricular pathology (right bundle-branch block and right axis deviation) and evidence of right-sided heart failure on examination (elevated jugular venous pressure, lower-extremity edema, tricuspid regurgitation). The loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound and radiographic evidence of enlarged central pulmonary arteries also support the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale. COPD is the most common cause of pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale in the United States.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, worsening dyspnea, and signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure is pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's obesity and history of cigarette smoking put him at risk for cardiac ischemia and for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, these diagnoses are less likely given the physical and electrocardiographic findings consistent with right ventricular pathology.
questions.hint: The primary pathophysiology of this condition is increased right ventricular afterload leading to progressive right ventricular hypertrophy, which, over time, results in right-sided heart failure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a one-year history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and light-headedness. She has never smoked cigarettes but reports heavy use of both alcohol and methamphetamine for approximately 10 years, until about 15 years ago. On examination, she has a 3/6 systolic murmur most audible at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration, a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound, clear lungs, and 1+ bilateral edema of the lower extremities. What additional finding would you expect to hear on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: An S4 gallop audible at the apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position
An S3 gallop audible over the left sternal border with the patient lying supine
A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur audible over the upper right sternal border
An S3 gallop audible at the apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position
A rumbling diastolic murmur audible at the apex

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left-sided gallops are best heard with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position and listening at the apex. Extra sounds that are heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position are most typically associated with diseases affecting the left ventricle.

B) CORRECT:

In a patient with clear lungs, the findings of a 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. The remote history of methamphetamine use is a risk factor for the development of pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension is often associated with a right-sided S3 or S4 gallop. To confirm this heart sound, it is optimal to ask the patient to lie supine and inspire and then to auscultate over the left sternal border.

Right-sided systolic murmurs and gallops tend to become louder with inspiration, owing to increased right ventricular filling. Because the right ventricle is the most anterior cardiac chamber, positioning patients supinely and listening at the left sternal border helps distinguish right-sided sounds from those emanating from the laterally placed left ventricle.

Key learning point: In addition to a systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound, the heart sound most typical of pulmonary hypertension is a right-sided S3 or S4 gallop.

C) INCORRECT:

A systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur is most typical of aortic stenosis. Neither mitral nor aortic stenosis is typically seen in patients with methamphetamine-induced pulmonary hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Left-sided gallops are best heard with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position and listening at the apex. Extra sounds that are heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position are most typically associated with diseases affecting the left ventricle.

E) INCORRECT:

A rumbling diastolic murmur at the apex is most typical of mitral stenosis. Neither mitral nor aortic stenosis is typically seen in patients with methamphetamine-induced pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of hypothyroidism and antiphospholipid syndrome reports worsening dyspnea on exertion, beginning about 6 months ago. Physical examination reveals an increased second pulmonary heart sound and trace lower-extremity edema. Her oxygen saturation is 95% while she is breathing ambient air and decreases to 91% with ambulation. Pulmonary function testing is normal, with the exception of a reduced diffusion capacity at 55% of predicted. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular function and estimates the pulmonary artery systolic pressure at 54 mm Hg. Which one of the following diagnostic studies is most likely to identify a cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Noncontrast high-resolution CT scan of the thorax

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contrast CT of the chest might also be helpful in this situation, but a noncontrast CT is likely to have a low yield.

B) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas testing might help to confirm hypoxemia but also would not identify an etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiogram has a low diagnostic yield when valvular disease is not suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiopulmonary exercise testing may further increase suspicion of pulmonary hypertension if a patient has exercise-induced desaturation, but it would not help to identify a specific etiology.

E) CORRECT:

An increased second heart sound, lower-extremity edema, exercise-induced oxygen desaturation, and a reduced diffusion capacity all strongly suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. A history of hypothyroidism and antiphospholipid syndrome may increase risk for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension. An appropriate diagnostic study is a pulmonary ventilation-perfusion scan.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with features of the antiphospholipid syndrome, worsening dyspnea on exertion, and exercise-induced oxygen desaturation is chronic thromboembolic pulmonary disease with resulting pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which one of the following tests is the most appropriate initial screening for patients with suspected pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing, right heart catheterization, ventilation-perfusion scanning, and high-resolution CT of the chest are often performed for further evaluation of pulmonary hypertension after initial screening with TTE.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing, right heart catheterization, ventilation-perfusion scanning, and high-resolution CT of the chest are often performed for further evaluation of pulmonary hypertension after initial screening with TTE.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing, right heart catheterization, ventilation-perfusion scanning, and high-resolution CT of the chest are often performed for further evaluation of pulmonary hypertension after initial screening with TTE.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing, right heart catheterization, ventilation-perfusion scanning, and high-resolution CT of the chest are often performed for further evaluation of pulmonary hypertension after initial screening with TTE.

E) CORRECT:

When evaluating a patient with signs and symptoms that suggest pulmonary hypertension, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the test of choice for initial screening. TTE findings that suggest pulmonary hypertension include elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure, right ventricular dysfunction, and an enlarged right ventricle. TTE is also helpful in evaluating for left-sided heart disease, the most common cause of pulmonary hypertension.

Key learning point: Echocardiography is the most appropriate initial test for screening patients with suspected pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-year history of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. She has a history of methamphetamine use but quit 5 years ago. Physical examination shows jugular venous pulsations 9 cm above the sternal angle. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is a normal S1 and a loud, split S2. An impulse can be felt with the fingers left of the sternum. The fingertips are enlarged and the nails are curved. There is pitting edema around the ankles bilaterally. A chest x-ray study shows pronounced central pulmonary arteries and a prominent right heart border. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: High-resolution CT scan of the lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) can be used to diagnose pulmonary embolism (PE). Chronic thromboembolic disease can cause group 4 pulmonary hypertension, and would fit with the duration of her symptoms, however V/Q scan is actually preferred as it is more sensitive for this diagnosis. Furthermore, her presentation is consistent with an alternate subgroup of pulmonary hypertension and CTA will not confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

High-resolution CT scan of the lung is used in the diagnosis of interstitial lung disease (ILD), which can cause group 3 pulmonary hypertension. ILD may cause fatigue, dyspnea, and clubbing of the nails. However, ILD typically also manifests with bibasilar, inspiratory crackles on auscultation, and reticular opacities on chest x-ray. This patient's presentation is more consistent with an alternate subgroup and CT will not confirm the diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Right-heart catheterization is the confirmatory test of choice for the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension as well as the specific subgroup, in this case pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Diagnosis is made when the mean pulmonary artery pressure is ≥ 20 mm Hg at rest and there is no evidence of underlying pulmonary and left heart conditions (e.g., valvular heart disease, systolic dysfunction, diastolic dysfunction). While PAH is often idiopathic, amphetamine and cocaine use have been associated with development of PAH. This patient has evidence of right-sided heart failure from her PAH, resulting in cor pulmonale. This indicates a worse prognosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing can be used to diagnose certain connective tissue diseases, such as scleroderma (SSc), which are associated with group 1 pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary arterial hypertension). This patient lacks other typical features of SSc, such as hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and dysphagia. Moreover, serologic testing would only confirm the presence of a connective tissue disorder, not confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Spirometry is used to diagnose obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) and restrictive lung disease, which can cause group 3 pulmonary hypertension. While her smoking status and symptoms could be consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, her overall presentation is suggestive of an alternate subgroup of pulmonary hypertension and spirometry will not confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with dyspnea, evidence of right-sided heart failure (peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, split S2), and pronounced central pulmonary arteries, all of which are strongly suggestive of pulmonary hypertension, likely related to her history of drug use. Correct diagnosis is imperative, as treatment options vary between types of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressive swelling of her legs, shortness of breath on exertion, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months. She has also had nausea and decreased appetite. She is being treated with paclitaxel for ovarian cancer and has had 2 episodes of pulmonary embolism during the past year. She does not drink alcoholic beverages or use other substances. BMI is 20 kg/m2. Pulse is 115/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a protuberant abdomen with a fluid wave and shifting dullness, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. There is visible distention of the jugular veins. The remainder of the physical examination, including lung auscultation, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer is a risk factor for liver metastases, which can, in some cases, manifest with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension and ascites) and/or peripheral edema if part of the hepatic venous system is compressed. In the majority of cases, however, liver metastases are asymptomatic. Moreover, they do not explain this patient's jugular venous distention.

B) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of paclitaxel include hepatotoxicity, peripheral edema, and nausea. However, paclitaxel-associated hepatotoxicity is usually limited to asymptomatic elevations of serum aminotransferases; abdominal distension and ascites are not common. Moreover, the toxicity profile of paclitaxel does not explain this patient's jugular venous distention.

C) CORRECT:

Signs of systemic venous congestion (JVD and bilateral lower extremity edema) and reduced right heart output (dyspnea on exertion with clear lungs on auscultation) are consistent with right heart failure. This patient's right ventricular failure is likely due to recurrent malignancy-associated pulmonary embolism, which leads to an increase in pulmonary artery pressure and right ventricular afterload. Over time, this increased ventricular afterload induces right heart remodeling with consequent right ventricular dysfunction. In severe cases, patients may also develop features of hepatic congestion (e.g., abdominal distention and ascites) and/or gastric congestion (e.g., nausea and early satiety). Management of decompensated right heart failure includes oxygen therapy (if the patient is hypoxemic), fluid restriction, diuretic therapy, and treatment of any underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis manifests with peripheral edema, nausea, early satiety, abdominal pain, and ascites. Cirrhosis does not, however, explain this patient's jugular venous distention. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic findings of cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, telangiectasia, caput medusae). In addition, this patient has no known risk factors for cirrhosis (e.g., history of significant alcohol use, obesity, chronic hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome manifests with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension and ascites), and this patient's history of ovarian cancer increases the risk of developing this condition (due to cancer-associated hypercoagulability). Budd-Chiari syndrome does not, however, explain this patient's jugular venous distention.
questions.hint: Consider the patient's history of thromboembolic events as a potential clue to the underlying pathology.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath and a persistent cough producing scant sputum. He reports new-onset swelling in both lower legs over the past few weeks. He has a 25-year history of heavy smoking. On examination, there is jugular venous distension, a loud component of the second heart sound best heard in the left second intercostal space, and bilateral pedal edema. Breath sounds are diminished in the apices with occasional wheezes.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephrotic syndrome causes edema due to proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia, but does not explain the pulmonary findings or loud second heart sound. The absence of renal signs like frothy urine or periorbital edema, along with the smoking history and pulmonary symptoms, suggests a cardiopulmonary rather than renal cause.

B) CORRECT:

Cor pulmonale manifests as right-sided heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension, often secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from long-term smoking. Chronic alveolar hypoxia leads to pulmonary vasoconstriction, increasing pulmonary arterial pressure. This pressure overload causes right ventricular hypertrophy and failure. Clinical signs include jugular venous distension, a loud pulmonary component of the second heart sound, and bilateral pedal edema. The diminished breath sounds and wheezing suggest underlying COPD, reinforcing the diagnosis of cor pulmonale.

Key learning point: In a patient with a history of heavy smoking and respiratory symptoms, bilateral lower limb swelling, elevated JVP, and a loud P2 suggest cor pulmonale due to pulmonary hypertension from chronic lung disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis can cause right-sided heart failure signs, but typically includes a pericardial knock and history of tuberculosis, cardiac surgery, or radiation. The loud pulmonary component of the second heart sound and diminished breath sounds suggest a pulmonary process. The smoking history and respiratory findings indicate a pulmonary cause rather than pericardial.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilated cardiomyopathy primarily involves impaired systolic function and ventricular dilation, often presenting with left-sided heart failure signs like an S3 gallop or pulmonary rales. The loud pulmonary component of the second heart sound and smoking history suggest pulmonary hypertension, not myocardial disease. The absence of an apically displaced impulse or a history of alcohol use or myocarditis further argues against dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and new-onset bilateral leg edema for the past 2 weeks. He has long-standing COPD. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention, a prominent parasternal heave, and a soft high-pitched murmur best heard along the left sternal border. He has no chest pain.


Heart rate
105/min


Oxygen saturation
89% on room air


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to investigate possible cor pulmonale in this patient?

choices.text: High-resolution CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right heart catheterization directly measures pulmonary artery pressures and right ventricular hemodynamics but is invasive. It is reserved for cases where noninvasive studies are inconclusive or detailed hemodynamic measurements are needed. Initial evaluation of cor pulmonale typically begins with noninvasive imaging like transthoracic echocardiography.

B) INCORRECT:

A high-resolution CT scan of the chest evaluates lung parenchymal abnormalities, such as interstitial lung diseases or emphysematous changes in COPD. However, it does not provide direct information about cardiac structure and hemodynamics, which are essential for assessing cor pulmonale.

C) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is the primary non-invasive imaging modality for assessing right ventricular structure and function, crucial in evaluating suspected cor pulmonale in patients with advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). TTE provides insights into right ventricular hypertrophy, chamber dilation, and pulmonary hypertension by estimating pulmonary artery systolic pressures through Doppler assessment of tricuspid regurgitant flow. Chronic hypoxemia in COPD can lead to pulmonary vasoconstriction and remodeling, increasing pressure on the right heart. TTE delineates these hemodynamic changes and assists in monitoring right-sided cardiac involvement, informing management strategies.

Key learning point: In a patient with COPD presenting with signs of right-sided heart failure, an echocardiogram is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for cor pulmonale and assess cardiac function.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels can indicate cardiac stress but lack specificity for assessing right ventricular anatomy and pulmonary pressures. BNP levels can be influenced by various factors, making them less effective than imaging for evaluating right-sided cardiac structures and pulmonary hemodynamics.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath over the last 6 months. He has a history of pulmonary embolism treated 2 years ago. Physical examination reveals a prominent P2 heart sound and mild jugular venous distention. Recent transthoracic echocardiography shows elevated pulmonary artery pressures with no obvious valvular abnormalities.

Oxygen saturation
98% at rest

Which diagnostic test is most likely to detect an underlying chronic thromboembolic cause for his pulmonary hypertension?

choices.text: High-resolution computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scans are the preferred initial diagnostic test for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). They detect mismatched perfusion defects, where areas of the lung are ventilated but not perfused due to thromboembolic obstruction. This test is highly sensitive for identifying regional perfusion abnormalities associated with chronic thromboembolic disease, especially in patients with a history of pulmonary embolism and signs of pulmonary hypertension, such as elevated pulmonary artery pressures and a prominent P2 heart sound.

Key learning point: A ventilation-perfusion lung scan is the most sensitive test for diagnosing chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), as it can detect perfusion defects caused by chronic thromboembolic disease.
Image Description:

Nuclear medicine ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan of a patient with a recent history of bilateral pleuritic chest pain; A: ventilation image (20.1 mCi of Xenon-133 gas), posterior projection; B: perfusion image (4.1 mCi of Technetium-99m-labeled macroaggregated albumin), posterior projection

The ventilation image shows uniform distribution of gas throughout the lungs, indicating normal ventilation. The perfusion image shows bilateral wedge-shaped defects (examples indicated by red overlay) from pulmonary emboli. Mismatched perfusion defects may also be seen in a variety of other settings, including venoocclusive disease, pulmonary artery obstruction from tumor, and radiation therapy.

H: heart

B) INCORRECT:

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest is designed to evaluate lung parenchyma and interstitial abnormalities, not the pulmonary vasculature. While it can show indirect signs like mosaic attenuation, it is not effective for identifying organized thrombi in the pulmonary arteries, which are crucial for diagnosing chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Comprehensive pulmonary function tests assess lung mechanics, volumes, and gas exchange, useful for parenchymal and airway diseases. They do not provide information on vascular obstruction or perfusion defects, which are necessary to diagnose chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Right heart catheterization measures hemodynamic parameters to confirm pulmonary hypertension but does not visualize thromboembolic material in the pulmonary vasculature. It quantifies severity rather than identifying the cause, making it unsuitable for detecting chronic thromboembolic lesions.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea, bilateral ankle swelling, and occasional palpitations. He has a 30-year history of COPD and continues to smoke two packs per day. He is on optimal bronchodilator therapy. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure and a loud P2. Echocardiogram demonstrates elevated pulmonary artery pressure. He reports decreasing exercise tolerance. Renal and liver function tests are normal (see lab result).

Oxygen saturation
87% on room air



Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
185 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term intervention to improve his survival and manage this complication?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low-dose diuretics alleviate symptoms of volume overload, such as peripheral edema, but do not address the underlying hypoxemia causing pulmonary hypertension in COPD. They do not improve survival or modify the disease process responsible for pulmonary vascular remodeling.

B) INCORRECT:

Short daily bursts of oxygen do not improve long-term survival in COPD patients with chronic hypoxemia. Continuous or prolonged oxygen therapy (at least 15 hours daily) is necessary to reverse hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and reduce mortality risk. Intermittent oxygen may temporarily relieve symptoms but does not address the persistent hypoxemia driving pulmonary hypertension.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and persistent hypoxemia (oxygen saturation <88%), continuous home oxygen therapy is essential. It reduces hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction, a major cause of pulmonary hypertension. Hypoxemia leads to vasoconstriction in the pulmonary circulation, increasing pulmonary artery pressures and causing right ventricular strain, known as cor pulmonale. Long-term oxygen therapy improves arterial oxygenation, reduces pulmonary vascular resistance, and slows pulmonary hypertension progression. It also addresses secondary erythrocytosis, as indicated by elevated hemoglobin, by reducing the hypoxic stimulus for red blood cell production. These effects enhance exercise tolerance and survival.

Key learning point: In COPD patients with pulmonary hypertension and potential hypoxemia, long-term oxygen therapy is indicated to improve survival and manage complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary arterial vasodilators are not beneficial in COPD-related pulmonary hypertension, which is due to chronic hypoxic vasoconstriction. They may worsen ventilation-perfusion mismatch and hypoxemia. Long-term oxygen therapy is more effective in managing COPD-induced pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. She has no family history of serious illness and does not smoke. She has been taking diethylpropion for appetite control and has lost 4.5 kg over the past 5 months. She is 163 cm tall and weighs 115 kg; BMI is 44. Her pulse is 83/min and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination reveals a loud pulmonary component of S2. Abdominal examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her shortness of breath?

choices.text: Blockade of the right bundle branch.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of pulmonary vascular walls is the underlying cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension, which can result from toxicity caused by sympathomimetic appetite suppressants and presents with dyspnea on exertion. This patient's heart sounds are typical of pulmonary hypertension, which initially presents with a prominent S2. Increased resistance of the pulmonary vasculature in pulmonary arterial hypertension limits right ventricular cardiac output; as it progresses, right ventricular failure can develop (e.g., cor pulmonale).

Key learning point: Sympathomimetic appetite suppressants can cause pulmonary arterial hypertension through hyperplasia and hypertrophy of pulmonary vascular walls, leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right heart strain.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophy of the interventricular septum is seen in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. While this condition can cause shortness of breath, it is characterized by an outflow obstruction in the left ventricle, not the right ventricle. Thus, an aortic systolic ejection murmur or paradoxical split S2 would be expected, not the loud pulmonary component of S2 seen in this patient. Furthermore, neither an S4 expected of a noncompliant hypertrophied ventricle nor a family history of sudden cardiac death in young relatives is present with this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the pulmonary valve can cause pulmonary stenosis, resulting in fatigue, dyspnea, and splitting of S2. Calcification of the pulmonary valve is rare but can occur secondary to congenital heart disease, carcinoid heart disease, or age-related changes. This patient is not in a high-risk age group nor does she have any signs of congenital or carcinoid heart disease which would suggest calcification.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the pulmonary interstitium is seen in pulmonary fibrosis. While dyspnea and fatigue are typical of this disease, a persistent dry cough would also be expected. Furthermore, unlike bleomycin, methotrexate, and amiodarone, diethylpropion is not known to cause pulmonary fibrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Right bundle branch block (RBBB) is a cardiac conduction deficit that can cause a widely split S2. Although RBBB can manifest with dyspnea due to underlying diseases, it is typically asymptomatic.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are likely due to a catastrophic adverse effect of diethylpropion, a sympathomimetic appetite suppressant. The accentuated pulmonary component of the second heart sound is the key to diagnosing this patient's condition.

questions.text: You are seeing a 28-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma who presents with a 6-month history of progressively worsening dyspnea. On examination, she has an accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and a grade 2/4 diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border. Jugular venous distention is measured at 10 cm, and there is 1+ lower-extremity edema. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by elevated jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, and a pericardial knock. An accentuated P2 heart sound or a right ventricular heave is not characteristic of constrictive pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus would produce a continuous, machinery-like murmur.

C) CORRECT:

Scleroderma is one of the more common connective tissue diseases to result in pulmonary arterial hypertension, in which there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance, with subsequent hypertrophy of the right ventricle. Cardiac examination findings characteristic of pulmonary arterial hypertension include an accentuated P2 heart sound (related to the forceful closure of the pulmonic valve), a right ventricular heave (related to right ventricular hypertrophy), and elevated right heart filling pressures. The diastolic murmur of pulmonic regurgitation (a so-called Graham Steell murmur) may also be audible, as in this patient.

Key learning point: An accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and evidence of right heart failure are most consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., right-to-left intracardiac shunting, cyanosis, and polycythemia) is caused by pulmonary hypertension related to a congenital defect between the right and left heart circulations. Scleroderma does not cause Eisenmenger syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is most often a congenital condition that produces a systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. The P2 component is usually soft, not accentuated.

questions.text: You are seeing a 60-year-old man with obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and a history of cigarette smoking who presents for evaluation of worsening dyspnea. He reports a chronic productive cough. His oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On examination, there is a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound, elevated jugular venous pressure, and significant bilateral lower-extremity edema. Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly, enlarged central pulmonary arteries, and hyperinflated lungs. Electrocardiogram reveals a right bundle-branch block and right axis deviation. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely to explain his worsening dyspnea?

choices.text: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
Exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has cor pulmonale that is secondary to pulmonary hypertension. He has electrocardiographic evidence of right ventricular pathology (right bundle-branch block and right axis deviation) and evidence of right-sided heart failure on examination (elevated jugular venous pressure, lower-extremity edema, tricuspid regurgitation). The loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound and radiographic evidence of enlarged central pulmonary arteries also support the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale. COPD is the most common cause of pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale in Canada.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a 60-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, worsening dyspnea, and signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure is pulmonary hypertension with cor pulmonale.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's obesity and history of cigarette smoking put him at risk for cardiac ischemia and for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, these diagnoses are less likely given the physical and electrocardiographic findings consistent with right ventricular pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

A COPD exacerbation is a consideration in this patient given his productive cough and wheeze, but he does not report a change in the quantity or quality of his sputum, and a COPD exacerbation alone would not explain his other examination findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's obesity and history of cigarette smoking put him at risk for cardiac ischemia and for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, these diagnoses are less likely given the physical and electrocardiographic findings consistent with right ventricular pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumonia can manifest atypically, but this patient has no findings to suggest acute infection (e.g., fever, change in sputum production, or opacity on chest radiograph).
questions.hint: The primary pathophysiology of this condition is increased right ventricular afterload leading to progressive right ventricular hypertrophy, which, over time, results in right-sided heart failure.

questions.text: You are seeing a 55-year-old woman who presents with a one-year history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and light-headedness. She has never smoked, but has a history of heavy alcohol and methamphetamine use for about 10 years, which she stopped 15 years ago. On examination, you note a 3/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration, a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound, clear lungs, and 1+ bilateral lower extremity edema. Which one of the following additional findings would you expect to hear on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: An S4 gallop audible at the apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position.
A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur audible over the upper right sternal border.
An S3 gallop audible at the apex with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position.
An S3 gallop audible over the left sternal border with the patient lying supine.
A rumbling diastolic murmur audible at the apex.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left-sided gallops are best heard with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position and listening at the apex. Extra sounds that are heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position are most typically associated with diseases affecting the left ventricle.

B) INCORRECT:

A systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur is most typical of aortic stenosis. Neither mitral nor aortic stenosis is typically seen in patients with methamphetamine-induced pulmonary hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Left-sided gallops are best heard with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position and listening at the apex. Extra sounds that are heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position are most typically associated with diseases affecting the left ventricle.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with clear lungs, the findings of a 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. The remote history of methamphetamine use is a risk factor for the development of pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension is often associated with a right-sided S3 or S4 gallop. To confirm this heart sound, it is optimal to ask the patient to lie supine and inspire and then to auscultate over the left sternal border.

Right-sided systolic murmurs and gallops tend to become louder with inspiration, owing to increased right ventricular filling. Because the right ventricle is the most anterior cardiac chamber, positioning patients supinely and listening at the left sternal border helps distinguish right-sided sounds from those emanating from the laterally placed left ventricle.

Key learning point: In addition to a systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration and a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound, the heart sound most typical of pulmonary hypertension is a right-sided S3 or S4 gallop.

E) INCORRECT:

A rumbling diastolic murmur at the apex is most typical of mitral stenosis. Neither mitral nor aortic stenosis is typically seen in patients with methamphetamine-induced pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: You are seeing a 48-year-old woman with a history of hypothyroidism and antiphospholipid syndrome who reports worsening dyspnea on exertion over the past 6 months. On examination, there is an increased second pulmonary heart sound and trace lower-extremity edema. Her oxygen saturation is 95% on room air and drops to 91% with ambulation. Pulmonary function testing is normal except for a reduced diffusion capacity at 55% of predicted. Transthoracic echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular function and an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 54 mm Hg. Which one of the following diagnostic studies is most likely to identify a cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Noncontrast high-resolution CT scan of the thorax.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiopulmonary exercise testing may further increase suspicion of pulmonary hypertension if a patient has exercise-induced desaturation, but it would not help to identify a specific etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas testing might help to confirm hypoxemia but also would not identify an etiology.

C) INCORRECT:

Contrast CT of the chest might also be helpful in this situation, but a noncontrast CT is likely to have a low yield.

D) CORRECT:

An increased second heart sound, lower-extremity edema, exercise-induced oxygen desaturation, and a reduced diffusion capacity all strongly suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. A history of hypothyroidism and antiphospholipid syndrome may increase risk for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension. An appropriate diagnostic study is a pulmonary ventilation-perfusion scan.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with features of the antiphospholipid syndrome, worsening dyspnea on exertion, and exercise-induced oxygen desaturation is chronic thromboembolic pulmonary disease with resulting pulmonary hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiogram has a low diagnostic yield when valvular disease is not suspected.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma presents to the emergency department with an episode of syncope today. She endorses a few months of progressive exertional dyspnea and chest pain. Vital signs are BP, 110/70 mm Hg; P, 98; R, 22; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F); SpO₂, 92% on room air. Physical examination shows a loud P2 heart sound, jugular vein distension, and lower extremity edema. ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy and right-axis deviation. Her chest x-ray is shown. Which diagnostic study will likely confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography is used to diagnose pulmonary embolism, a potential cause of pulmonary hypertension, but is unable to confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

CTA chest, abdomen, and pelvis is used to diagnose aortic dissection which is unlikely in this patient. The clinical findings suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests are used to diagnose COPD, a potential cause of pulmonary hypertension, but are unable to confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventilation/perfusion scintigraphy is used to diagnose pulmonary embolism, a potential cause of pulmonary hypertension, but is unable to confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Transthoracic echocardiography is the first-line noninvasive study for suspected pulmonary hypertension and can confirm the diagnosis by identifying elevated pulmonary artery pressures through increased tricuspid regurgitation velocity and signs of right heart strain

questions.text: A 42-year old woman with a history of pulmonary hypertension presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. Vital signs are BP, 100/60; P, 110; R, 25; SpO₂, 84% on room air. Which of the following is the preferred initial method of improving oxygenation in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – High-flow nasal cannula is the preferred initial oxygenation method for acute decompensated pulmonary hypertension because it provides effective oxygen delivery without the negative hemodynamic effects of positive pressure ventilation. Positive intrathoracic pressure from mechanical ventilation or noninvasive positive pressure ventilation can impair venous return and worsen shock in these preload-dependent patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Continuous positive airway pressure should be avoided if possible in acute decompensated pulmonary hypertension because positive intrathoracic pressure impairs venous return and can worsen shock in these preload-dependent patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Bilevel positive airway pressure should be avoided if possible in acute decompensated pulmonary hypertension because positive intrathoracic pressure impairs venous return and can worsen shock in these preload-dependent patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Mechanical ventilation should be avoided if possible in acute decompensated pulmonary hypertension because positive intrathoracic pressure impairs venous return and can worsen shock in these preload-dependent patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation is reserved for refractory right heart failure as a bridge to urgent lung or heart-lung transplant, not as an initial oxygenation strategy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with progressive dyspnea and fatigue for the past few months. Vital signs are BP, 120/70 mm Hg; P, 96; R, 24; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F); SpO₂, 90% on room air. On examination, he has jugular venous distention and a loud P2. His point-of-care ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular failure would typically cause left atrial dilation rather than right atrial and ventricular dilation seen in this ultrasound.

B) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade would cause right ventricular collapse during diastole rather than the dilated right ventricle seen in this ultrasound.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — Pulmonary hypertension causes increased right ventricular pressure leading to right ventricular hypertrophy and dilation, and an increased right ventricle to left ventricle size ratio as seen in this ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

While a massive pulmonary embolism can cause acute right ventricular dilation with signs of right heart strain, the clinical presentation suggests a more chronic process. A massive pulmonary embolism typically presents with acute hemodynamic instability rather than the progressive course seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypovolemia would cause small, underfilled cardiac chambers rather than the enlarged right ventricle and right atrium seen in the ultrasound. Additionally, hypovolemia would not produce jugular venous distention, which indicates elevated right-sided pressures rather than volume depletion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with known pulmonary arterial hypertension presents with worsening dyspnea over 2 days. Vital signs are BP, 82/45; P, 118; oxygen saturation, 87% on room air; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F). Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, hepatomegaly, and bilateral lower extremity edema. Laboratory results show elevated troponin and BNP. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Oxygen therapy and volume status assessment
Emergency echocardiogram to assess valve function

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Initial management should target SpO2 > 90% because hypoxia can lead to pulmonary vasoconstriction and worsen pulmonary arterial hypertension. Careful simultaneous assessment of volume status is essential, as targeting euvolemia requires balancing IV diuretics for volume overload and IV fluid challenges for hypovolemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Intubation and mechanical ventilation should be avoided if possible in acute decompensated pulmonary hypertension. Positive intrathoracic pressure can impair venous return and worsen shock in preload-dependent patients. Extreme caution and specialist consultation are required if mechanical ventilation is unavoidable.

C) INCORRECT:

Aggressive fluid resuscitation can worsen outcomes in acute decompensated pulmonary hypertension. The goal is euvolemia, which requires very close assessment of volume status, as both hypovolemia and hypervolemia are harmful to cardiac function. Fluids should be administered with caution and careful monitoring.

D) INCORRECT:

While diuretics may be needed for volume overload, high-dose furosemide without careful volume assessment can cause harmful hypovolemia. Management typically involves careful balancing of IV diuretics for volume overload and IV fluid challenges for hypovolemia based on close volume status assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

While echocardiography may be useful for evaluation, it is not the most appropriate immediate next step. The priority is addressing hypoxia with oxygen therapy and assessing volume status, as these interventions directly target the pathophysiology of acute decompensation and can be initiated immediately.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of mixed connective tissue disease presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and lower extremity swelling over several months. Vital signs are BP, 112/70 mm Hg; P, 94; R, 22; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F); SpO₂, 92% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension and peripheral edema. A diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension is suspected. Which of the following ultrasound findings would be most consistent with pulmonary hypertension?

choices.text: Small right ventricle with hyperdynamic left ventricular function
Pericardial effusion with right ventricular diastolic collapse
Right ventricular dilation with interventricular septal flattening
Left ventricular dilation with reduced ejection fraction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A small right ventricle with a hyperdynamic left ventricle suggests hypovolemia or distributive shock rather than pulmonary hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

A pericardial effusion with right ventricular diastolic collapse suggests cardiac tamponade rather than pulmonary hypertension.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Pulmonary hypertension causes right ventricular pressure overload resulting in right ventricular dilation and flattening of the interventricular septum.

D) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy suggsets systemic hypertension rather than pulmonary hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular dilation with reduced ejection fraction suggests heart failure rather than pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of interstitial lung disease presents to the emergency department with worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue over several months. Vital signs are BP, 116/74 mm Hg; P, 92; R, 20; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F); SpO₂, 90% on room air. A diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension is suspected. Which of the following ECG findings are most consistent with pulmonary hypertension?

choices.text: Diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR-segment depression
Left ventricular hypertrophy with left axis deviation
Right ventricular hypertrophy with right axis deviation
Q waves in the inferior leads

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR-segment depression suggests acute pericarditis rather than pulmonary hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Low-voltage QRS complexes suggests the presence of a pericardial effusion rather than pulmonary hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy with left axis deviation suggests left ventricular pressure overload from systemic hypertension or aortic stenosis rather than pulmonary hypertension.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Pulmonary hypertension causes chronic right ventricular pressure overload resulting in right ventricular hypertrophy with right axis deviation.

E) INCORRECT:

Q waves in the inferior leads suggest a prior inferior wall myocardial infarction rather than pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and lower extremity swelling over six months. She denies chest pain, fever, or orthopnea. Past medical history includes systemic sclerosis. Vital signs are BP, 130/70 mm Hg; P, 96; R, 22; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F); SpO₂, 90% on room air. Examination reveals a jugular vein distension, loud P2, and lower extremity edema. ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy with right axis deviation. Point-of-care ultrasound demonstrates a dilated right ventricle with interventricular septal flattening. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pericarditis typically presents with sharp, pleuritic chest pain that improves with sitting forward and is often accompanied by a pericardial friction rub with ECG findings of diffuse ST elevations rather than the right ventricular hypertrophy and right axis deviation seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of progressive dyspnea, right heart failure signs, loud P2, ECG findings of right ventricular hypertrophy with right axis deviation, and echocardiographic evidence of right ventricular dilation with interventricular septal flattening are characteristic of elevated pulmonary pressures causing chronic right heart strain.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis typically causes left heart strain with left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG rather than the right ventricular hypertrophy and right axis deviation seen here. The murmur of aortic stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that radiates to the carotids, whereas this patient has a loud P2 indicating elevated pulmonary pressures.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade classically presents with Beck triad of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck veins. While the patient has jugular vein distension, the other findings of Beck triad are not present.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation typically causes left ventricular volume overload with a characteristic high-pitched, decrescendo early diastolic murmur, not the loud P2 indicating elevated pulmonary pressures seen here. The ECG findings would show left ventricular hypertrophy rather than the right ventricular hypertrophy and right axis deviation observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with worsening dyspnea and new bilateral lower extremity swelling. He has a history of severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, a prominent parasternal heave, and 2+ pitting edema to the mid-shins. An echocardiogram confirms right ventricular hypertrophy and dilation with a preserved left ventricular ejection fraction.
